PETITION.TITLE: Australia: Christian Commonwealth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we, the undersigned, call for the full and total recognition, by Federal Parliament and the High Court and all government agencies that Australia is a Christian Commonwealth according to law and its heritage traditions and customs.

That as Australia prepares for the Centenary of Federation on 1st January, 2001 AD we celebrate our Centenary as a Christian Commonwealth as described by the Founders of Federation such as Sir John Downer, who said ``The Commonwealth will be from its first stage a Christian Commonwealth'' and as stated in our Federal Constitution-``Relying on the Blessings of Almighty God . . . ''
That our Federal Parliament therefore implement the following policies before 1st January, 2001 AD.
1. The Adoption of a Christian National Anthem-``God Bless Australia'' to the tune of ``Waltzing Matilda''.
2. The adoption of a Christian National Motto-``One Nation Under God'', for use on our coins, banknotes, etc.
3. The appointment of practising Christians as Vice Regal Representatives of our Christian Queen, Elizabeth II.
4. The retention of our Christian Prayers at the daily opening of Parliament in the standing respectful presence of all Members of Parliament.
5. The retention of ``God Save the Queen'' for Vice Regal Functions as our Royal Anthem and as our National Hymn for all other civic functions.
6. The retention of Christian Christmas Carols in our State Schools and other civic functions during the Christmas Season.
7. Officially inform the United Nations and all the other nations of the world that Australia is a Christian Commonwealth.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will reaffirm our Christian Heritage as a Christian Commonwealth.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

HIGHER EDUCATION FUNDING AMENDMENT BILL 1991

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Higher Education Funding Act 1988, which provides for Commonwealth grants of financial assistance to the States, the Australian Capital Territory, the Northern Territory and higher education institutions for the provision of higher education. The Bill provides increased funding for higher education institutions totalling some $171m over the 1991 to 1993 triennium.

In accordance with the Government's cost supplementation arrangements, the Bill provides for additional expenditure over the 1991 to 1993 triennium amounting to some $148m to take account of movements in the Department of Employment, Education and Training's Higher Education Salary and Non-salary Indexes.

The Bill also provides for $4.7m to be transferred, in each year of the 1991 to 1993 triennium, from the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Act 1988 to the Higher Education Funding Act 1988. The purpose of this transfer, agreed to between the Commonwealth and the Queensland State Government, is to enable higher education courses in Queensland which are currently located within the TAFE sector to be transferred to the higher education sector and funded as higher education courses. This will provide a more appropriate location for the future development of these courses, and will bring course provision in Queensland into line with that in other States.

The Bill takes account of altered arrangements for the Special Overseas Postgraduate Fund to enable expenditure under this Program to be spread over the period 1991 to 1994. Originally, $4.3m was notionally allocated for expenditure in 1990/91. The re-allocation of this money is designed to allow for a properly structured program and does not change the approved overall level of funding.

The Bill also provides for the transfer to 1991 of $2.2m in unexpended funds from the 1990 higher education research program. In addition, the Bill takes account of revised amounts for re-imbursement of HECS revenue to the States for State-funded places. These revisions have been made on the basis of up-dated information, obtained from the States, on the number of such places eligible for re-imbursement. Some $7m in additional expenditure will be provided for this purpose over the 1991 to 1993 triennium.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the Senate.
STATES GRANTS (TAFE ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1991

The States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill 1991 provides for supplementation to existing grants to the States for TAFE to reflect increases in price levels and adjusts funding levels to reflect the transfer of certain higher education places from the TAFE sector to the Higher Education sector.

The net effect of these changes is that the Bill provides for a reduction in funding levels of $0.386 million, the total available for technical and further education now being $358.201 million for 1991.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the Senate adjourned last night, I was speaking about the amendments that the Australian Democrats intend to move to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill 1991. Two of those amendments refer to the structure of the Bill which we believe, in at least those two areas, is deficient. I was paying tribute to the detailed work that Senator Watson has done on the provisions of the Bill, but there are two areas which have escaped his attention and which I understand do not enjoy his support, and I regret that.

SPEECH.PARA: Similarly, I am told that the Government is disinclined at this stage to support the amendments, and I wonder why that is so. One of them seeks to ensure that bad debts for which tax deductibility is obtained by companies, particularly financial institutions, that are operating overseas cannot be avoided. That tax deductibility is shifted to another country where there are no taxation agreements with Australia and, in this way, the tax deductibility is utilised for tax avoidance purposes. The Australian Democrats believe that part IVA should be hauled in at this point and that the onus should be on the taxpaying entity in that case to show that the transaction that has been used, which will achieve a tax benefit for the entity, has other normal commercial purposes as well. It is a loophole that should be closed and I again call on both the Opposition and the Government to assist us in closing it.

Another area that the Democrats believe deserves some attention is the extension of depreciation and other allowances for Australian companies engaged in commercial activities overseas, including building and construction activities. We believe that we should provide tax incentives for companies investing in Australia, not tax incentives for companies investing offshore. Once again, this measure deserves support from both the Government and the Opposition.

There are three other amendments which the Democrats will move. They seek to deny tax deductibility in three cases. In the case of high executive salaries, we believe that tax deductibility should be denied to salaries in excess of $200,000. The second item which we believe should not enjoy tax deductibility privileges in our system is the advertising of tobacco and alcohol. Yesterday I put on record the fact that drug abuse costs the Australian community more than $14.3 billion every year. Taxpayers should not be asked to subsidise that sort of expenditure, that sort of damage to our community. Finally, there is an amendment which seeks to deny tax deductibility for conferences held overseas by Australian organisations. If a professional organisation-be they doctors, engineers, architects, or whatever-has a conference in Hawaii, we do not see why the Australian taxpayer should subsidise such a joy-ride.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't want them to have knowledge of what happens overseas.

—In response to the interjection, we are perfectly happy to support conferences and seminars that are held in Australia by Australian organisations. Unless it can be shown that it is an international conference, we are quite happy to agree that tax deductibility should apply.

SPEECH.PARA: What we are seeking to knock on the head by this amendment is an Australian organisation holding a conference overseas for no reason other than wishing to have that conference in that location and enjoy, at the taxpayers' expense, a joy-ride. These are the amendments that the Democrats will move at the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill 1991, which was formerly the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6) 1990. It is an omnibus Bill covering a host of not necessarily related amendments. This Bill, amongst other things, gives effect to the personal income tax cuts that were announced in the Budget last year and brought into existence on 1 January 1991 and provides consequential amendments to the medical rebate. There are also measures which allow more accessibility to roll-over relief from capital gains liability and relief measures to remove potential for double taxation on foreign earnings. I will address these three points in more detail.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill will amend the income tax rates to reduce the lowest rate-that is, $5,401 to $20,700-from 21 per cent to 20 per cent. The Government tells us it is forgoing income of $430m in 1990-91 and $1 billion in a full year. It seems a big reduction when one looks at the overall Budget-and $1 billion is a considerable reduction-but when it comes down to the individual person on the top end of the lowest rate, which is $20,000, there is only a $200 saving. However, I suppose that, for one person, a $200 saving in a tax bill is certainly better than nothing.

I move on to the medical rebate. The lowering of the tax rate also lowers the rebate that persons get on money they spend medically over $1,000. The rebate will come down in direct proportion. The Government says that it will save $1m in one year in forgone deductions; in other words, it is credited to the Australian Taxation Office or Treasury.

As I said, capital gains tax relief will be more accessible for asset transfers within a company group. Where there is a change of assets between one fully owned company and another with totally the same shareholders, there is some liability, whether intended or unintended, for capital gains tax. This Bill will relieve that situation. Previous anti-avoidance rules required the issue of shares or security across the two companies to be of equal value and, when transferred, as a consideration of the transfer. We now have new provisions in the Bill where there is deemed to be a transfer of assets. If the shareholders of the company that is taking the assets lose effective control, then they will be liable for capital gains tax. Of course, the situation now is a lot clearer, more defined, and is necessary to make sure that there is no escaping the capital gains tax liabilities. These are the major provisions contained in the Bill, though there are some other minor ones. Irrespective of whether they are considered minor or major, they are there.

Unfortunately, this Bill is a continuation of this Government's ever-changing taxation legislation. Far too many amendments have been introduced. The explanatory memorandum is of record thickness. Obviously, this ever-growing taxation Act-I believe that it has increased six times in volume in not much more than the time I have been in this Parliament-means that measures are introduced without much research and thought and anomalies appear as time goes by. We have continual amendments. At least three or four times a year, with Senator McMullan on the other side leading for the Government, we sit in this chamber debating amendments to rectify the legislation. It is time that we wrote a complete new tax Act to sort those things out. Hopefully, we would not then be debating the legislation so often.

I suppose that we are paid to be here to debate these amendments in the Senate but further calculations have to be made and further hardships occur outside this place as a result of the amendments. One area that is affected is the continual increase in the cost of accounting. If we take a survey of the costs of businesses, we find that the accountancy fees for filing taxation returns and meeting statutory obligations have virtually doubled in Australia during the past two years. Senator McMullan is looking at me in surprise. I do not know whether he pays an accountant to prepare his taxation returns, but I do and I have noticed that the fees have doubled during the past two years, and I think they have quadrupled in --

TALK.START.PARA: —That is because you are making so much money.

—Because Senator McMullan is making so much money. Although Senator McMullan might be on a semi-Minister's salary, I am not. The situation is that accountancy fees are increasing and it is a growing concern. We could address that matter if we rewrote the tax Act.

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to other measures that this Government has taken during the past eight years-the ad hoc legislation it brings in and takes out. It gets back to the point I have already made about increasing accountancy fees. Honourable senators can see that. I have pointed many times to the number of measures introduced in the past few years which have then had to be taken out again. The first turnaround was probably about the ban on negative gearing. I know that former Senator Haines carried on about this in the Parliament during her long term here. The Government saw the folly of its ways when it introduced that measure because a turnaround in housing investment followed, and it had to change its policies. That measure worked against the Government and it pulled it out again because of public pressure and lack of investment.

We then had the famous jealousy tax-the luxury tax on cars. As will be seen from the Forward Estimates that will come before the Senate next week in connection with the luxury tax on cars, the Government is saying that withdrawing the tax in accordance with the industry statement will cost the revenue $400m. I do not know how the Government arrives at that figure. Senator McMullan, the semi-Minister at the table, might be able to tell us. That tax was supposed to raise $100m when it was announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) during the last Federal election campaign, for use on the black spots on the roads mainly in New South Wales and probably in other places. Figures published have shown that instead of an extra $100m being raised in sales tax on cars, there has been a loss of about $350m due to the lack of car sales. I suppose that there are certain other reasons why cars in general have not been selling in the current economic downturn. But how can the Government say that $400m in revenue is forgone by removing the luxury tax when it knows that it would have produced a negative result?

A few weeks ago when I asked Senator Button a question-I am still waiting for his answer-he did give an indication to the Senate that the luxury tax certainly was not working in that way. I have spoken to the motor dealers of higher priced cars, as well as the dealers of lower priced cars, and have been informed that even in the last fortnight there seems to have been a certain upturn in the sale of cars since the luxury tax, or jealousy tax, has been removed. This may not be attributed completely to the removal of that tax; it could be attributed partly to the lowering of interest rates that we have finally had in Australia in the last few months.

I move on to another tax that the Government introduced, I think in 1983-that is, the sales tax on hand tools used in production, primary industry and mining. It was not restricted to those areas, but they had been exempt before. The sales tax on tools was applied right across the board. In the industry statement of a month ago the tax was removed. So there is to be another change to the legislation and another change for retailers. Whether they have to charge sales tax is creating further confusion. Nonetheless, it is something that the Government has had to turn around on.

In 1983 or 1984 the Government introduced a sales tax on lubricants; in other words, lubrication oil in motors. We had the ridiculous situation at one stage where there was a sales tax on oil at one end of a machine and not on the oil at the other end. It was practically the same oil-one was engine lubricating oil and the other was hydraulic oil-yet sales tax applied to one and not to the other. One had to make certain applications and meet statutory requirements when one bought this sort of oil and that created confusion. The Government fixed that confusion by putting the sales tax on the whole lot. The Government has now seen how things are going and has taken the sales tax off again.

Sales tax, as a whole, certainly needs revamping. Of course we have the agenda for that when we are in government-a goods and services tax-but that will probably be a couple of years away. The Government has a couple of years to sort out a few of these things before it finally exits from government in this and the other place.

I refer to depreciation. The Government has had various goes at depreciation since it has been in office. Because of the concerns of the former Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, the depreciation schedules were changed from applying to not necessarily the life of a machine, the life of a tool, or the life of anything, to some schedule worked out by himself, his advisers or the Australian Taxation Office, which was totally ridiculous and unrelated to what one would normally use. The Government, once again, had to turn around and change that in the industry statement of last month. I give the Government some credit for the fact that it has brought depreciation more into line with the worthwhile life of machines that industy uses. For example, computer hardware and software change rapidly. In fact, technology changes in months rather than in years. People should be able to write off their equipment over a shorter period.

The same can be said of heavy machinery used in the mining industry, to which I am very close. One can write a machine off in the life of a project. If an open cut mine is developed and lasts only two years, I presume that machinery bought solely for that purpose will be looked at in that way.

I come to a point that Senator Spindler mentioned-that is, an investment allowance on Australian made goods. We had quite a liberal investment allowance in the days of the Fraser Government, and I believe it did a lot to encourage developers, farmers and miners to reinvest in plant in their businesses, which did help the economy of Australia. But, once again, when this Government came into power, the investment allowance virtually disappeared.

The fringe benefits tax has been a great mishmash since it was introduced by this Government. If we look at a Price Waterhouse publication of last month, which dealt with this matter, we see that in that booklet alone there is enough to fill half the taxation Act. This publication relates solely to the fringe benefits tax and certain unintended consequences of its introduction. The tax was introduced mainly to deal with the car and housing situation of employees, no matter where they were in Australia. It has spread from one thing to another and now we almost need a bible to cover just the fringe benefits tax.

This is probably the most obnoxious tax to hit the remote areas of Australia that could have been introduced by any government. Originally I fully supported the fringe benefits tax measures because I believed there were too many rorts in the system by which wages were transferred into non-taxable benefits, but we have to look at what sorts of benefits are non-taxable. I believe that an employer paying the school fees of the children of an employee living in the centre of Sydney, Melbourne, Perth or Adelaide should pay tax on that benefit. He should be hit with a fringe benefits tax. But an employer providing accommodation on the edge of the Gibson Desert in a mining camp, oil camp or whatever is not providing any fringe benefit whatsoever. He will not get anyone out there unless he provides housing.

I mention another point that was raised only a few weeks ago by a headmaster of a school in Perth. It is a boarding school working on a house system. There is a family looking after, say, 160 boys aged from 12 to 17 in a family situation. This family lives in the end of a four-story block with 160 adolescent boys. Can anyone tell me where the fringe benefit is in those quarters? The person in charge and spouse are at the beck and call of those boys. If somebody has a stomach ache or whatever at three o'clock in the morning, they must attend. Can someone tell me why the supply of those quarters is classed as a fringe benefit? Those people have to live there and to put up with what is there. Does that qualify for fringe benefits tax or not?

The capital gains tax introduced by this Government is the one we were not going to have, but we have got it. Of course, the unintended consequences of the capital gains tax are also the subject of this legislation.

I would just like to go through the Democrat amendments of Senator Spindler, which he told us about some time ago. I do not think the first amendment is necessary; it is self-evident. He talks of certain wages or salaries which are not deductible. The amendment says that the following should not be deductible:
. . . in respect of that amount of the salary or wages of an employee which exceeds $200,000.
I believe that this is another jealousy amendment by the Australian Democrats and I leave that point there.

Last night, Senator Spindler talked about the way in which investment in Australia encourages companies to go offshore. I know why companies go offshore. Because of the work practices in this country and because they cannot make a profit. But what better way to drive our top personnel offshore than a proposal such as that suggested by the Democrats? Can I be told what more could be done to drive them offshore? For a suitably qualified person I do not think $200,000 is such a high figure when one has in mind top management and top surgeons for instance. Surgeons are hardly on wages, although they could be in certain hospitals. What better way is there to drive such people offshore? This is what will happen if we do not reward excellence and if these things are not deductible. I think that the proposal is ridiculous. TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL NO 6
ADVANCE QUESTIONS TO BE TAKEN ON NOTICE FOR COMMITTEE STAGES OF THE BILL
QUESTION 1. (Clauses 95,96)

I refer to the precedent in Income Tax Regulations, 1990, No 398 preceding the enabling legislation in Taxation Laws Amendment Bill No 6 1990, in that regulations adjusting the rate of tax instalment deductions may validly be made before the Bill is enacted.
How far in the Attorney-General's opinion can regulations of this nature precede Statute Law?
Is this a case of administrative law usurping Statute Law even for limited periods?
ANSWER NO. 1

Section 221C of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 authorises the making of regulations to prescribe rates of deductions to be made by employers from salary or wages to enable collection of income tax from employees under the pay-as-you-earn system.
2. Advice from Attorney-General's Department makes the following points:
* regulations made under section 221C are valid if their purpose is to enable the collection of instalments of income tax imposed by an Act;

* the rates of deduction prescribed by the regulations are an estimate only of tax finally payable by an employee and they are not designed to collect the net amount payable on assessment-the amount collected by deduction is taken into account at year's end when an employee's liability for tax is assessed and the law provides for an adjustment where too much or too little tax has been deducted; and

* regulations enable the collection by instalments of income tax imposed at the rates operative for that year-the regulations retain that purpose even though they enable less tax to be collected than would be the case if the rates of deduction were specifically based on existing rather than proposed rates of tax.

3. As the regulations do not determine the ultimate liability of an individual for tax it is not a case of them usurping Statute Law. In this instance, the purpose of the regulations is fundamentally different to that of the Statute Law.

4. Attorney-General's Department advises that there is no legislative link between the regulations for setting the rates of PAYE deduction and the rates of tax contained in the Income Tax Rates Act 1986 which the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill seeks to amend. QUESTION 6 (Clauses 61 and 62)

The legislation that is now being proposed under the proposed Division l9A of Part IIIA of the Act is inequitable in that it does not provide for differential treatment between company groups which have a horizontal structure and those with a vertical structure.

The underlying purpose of the proposed Division is to ensure that taxpayers are not able to accelerate or create capital losses by disposal or shares, or debt owed by, a company which has previously transferred an asset at less than the lesser of indexed cost base or market value to another company under ` `common ownership''.

The legislation purporting to achieve this aim, is set out in Clause 61 of this Bill. However, it is drafted with such breadth as to apply in circumstances where there is no diminution in value in the shares or debt of the transferor company. This is particularly so where companies are held in a vertical as opposed to a triangular chain.

In a simple vertical post capital gains structure of company ownership, company B is a direct subsidiary of company A. Therefore, company A and Company B are under common ownership by reason of their being group companies in terms of Section 160zzo.

If Company A were to transfer an asset at less than the lesser of the indexed cost base or market value to company B, Division l9A would require a reduction in the cost base of the shares in Company A (supposedly to reflect a decrease in the value of Company A) and a compensatory increase in the cost base of the shares in Company B.

However, given the vertical nature of the structure, there is no diminution in the value of Company A as the asset has simply been transferred to its own subsidiary. Therefore there should be no need to adjust the cost base of shares in company A. Likewise, if no adjustment were made to the cost base of shares in company A, there would be no need for a compensatory adjustment in company B.
This apparent anomaly will arise at any time a parent company transfers an asset at diminished value to any subsidiary in a vertical chain.

Further to what has been said, Division l9a would be administratively unworkable where the transferor company was a listed public company. In such circumstances a group asset transfer by listed public companies would require the cost base of all post Capital gains tax shareholdings in listed public companies to be reduced on an individual shareholder basis.

This reduction would be made having regard to the proportion the market value of each shareholder's post capital gains tax shares bears to the market value of total post capital gains tax shareholdings of listed companies.

The information required to determine this reduction would not be readily available to shareholders and to expect a listed public company to provide such information on an individual shareholder basis is, with respect, somewhat unreasonable. (I have been informed that it would be sufficient to meet the anti avoidance objects of the proposed amendments for the liability to subsist for a fixed period of say seven years. This would then correspond with the position in the UK.)

QUESTION 15 (Clauses 101, 102)
What is the nature of the loopholes intended to be rectified by amendments under Part 5 of the bill relating to the secrecy provisions to the Taxation Administration Act 1953?
Do the provisions extend to questionable releases of information under the Freedom of Information Act?
ANSWER NO. 15
PART A
Section 8xa

The existing section 8xa of the Taxation Administration Act makes it an offence for a person knowingly to take action to obtain information held under or for the purposes of a taxation law, unless the person takes the action in the course of exercising powers under a taxation law. The term ``taxation law'' is defined to mean, broadly, the Commonwealth tax laws administered by the Commissioner of Taxation.

2. The effect of the section is very broad. It is being interpreted in some quarters as applying to prevent a person from taking action to obtain information held anywhere in the community (i.e. other than by the Commissioner) where the creation of the information is associated in some way with a Commonwealth taxation law, unless the person is taking the action in the course of exercising powers or functions under or in relation to such a law. This information could include, for example, copies of group certificates, fringe benefits tax returns and PPS papers held by businesses for their own records and also copies of profit and loss statements, balance sheets and wage books where they are prepared in conjunction with a taxation law.
3. Section 8xa as it currently stands is having an unintended effect on the activities of the State and Territory tax authorities.

4. Prior to the enactment of section 8xa in 1989 the State and Territory authorities had access to the records held by business in ensuring compliance with their laws. However, in some quarters section 8xa is being interpreted to deny the relevant tax authorities access to this information, required for audit in relation to a State or Territory tax, on the basis that the information is held for Commonwealth taxation purposes in accordance with section 8xa.

5. The change to section 8xa by the Bill will make it an offence for a person to take action to obtain access to records containing information about a person's affairs where those records are in the Commissioner's possession. It will not therefore apply in respect of access to records that are in the possession of someone other than the Commissioner. An offence as a consequence of illegal access to information held other than by the Commissioner is covered by the general law (e.g. criminal law).
Section 8xb
6. Section 8xb creates an offence where a person makes a record of, or divulges, information about the affairs of a taxpayer that is or was in the possession of the Commissioner

and is obtained in breach of a taxation law. The Bill proposes to amend section 8xb so that an offence is created where the unlawful recipient of taxation information uses that information, in a manner whereby it is neither recorded nor divulged.

7. This amendment is designed to prevent the solicitation and use of confidential taxpayer information by persons (such as those providing credit reference services) where the disclosure to them would breach a taxation secrecy provision. The amendment follows a similar amendment to the Social Security Act 1947 in 1989.
PART B

8. Sections 8xa and 8xb are directed at preventing persons not employed by, or performing services for, the Australian Taxation Office from illegally obtaining or making use of information that is or was at some time held by the Commissioner of Taxation. They do not deal with releases of information under the Freedom of Information Act 1982.

9. The Commissioner of Taxation or his officers may release information in accordance with the Freedom of Information Act. In doing so regard must be had to the exemption provisions of the Freedom of Information Act including the extent to which the information is protected by a taxation secrecy provision.
10. The proposed amendments to sections 8xa and 8xb are supported by the Privacy Commissioner.
QUESTION 16 (Clause 44)
I am concerned that the proposed amendment to partnerships does not achieve the intended clarification referred to in the Explanatory Memorandum.

Clause 44 of the Bill proposes an amendment to section 160a of the Act to include within the definition of ``asset'' for Capital Gains Tax purposes a taxpayer's interest in a partnership asset of a partnership in which the taxpayer is a partner. Whilst this amendment would extend the definition by specifically including such assets, the proposed amendment does not achieve the intended clarification referred to in the Explanatory Memorandum. This is because a ``partner's chose in action'', being the interest in the partnership itself, is not excluded from 160(a).
Could this be clarified?
ANSWER NO. 16

Senator Watson is concerned that the amendments proposed by clause 44, which will include in the definition of ``asset'' for the purposes of section 160a a partner's interest in a partnership asset, could result in ``double taxation'' on the disposal of a partnership interest. This is because a partnership interest, being a chose in action, is itself an asset for CGT purposes, yet a large part of the value of such an interest may in turn relate to interests in individual assets which themselves are treated as separate assets for CGT purposes.

There are strong legal presumptions against double taxation which, in the Government's view, would prevent the potential problems foreseen by Senator Watson. However, as the issue is obviously the cause of some concern, the Government proposes a further amendment to the Bill which will ensure that a ``partnership interest'' is itself treated as an asset only to the extent that its value does not relate to interests in individual assets, which are separately subject to CGT.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Watson for the cooperative attitude he has shown in the development of the discussion around the issues that he has raised-and others-some of which have led to technical amendments to the Bill, others which will require further consideration and some on which I think we may have satisfied Senator Watson that no amendments were required. I do not want to suggest at this stage that this practice, which we have developed now twice in a row, of incorporating in Hansard lengthy answers to a series of questions is something which I necessarily want to do on every occasion-it may or may not be appropriate-but I do appreciate the manner in which it has been undertaken on this occasion.

SPEECH.PARA: I will not go through every point that was made during the second reading debate, much of which related more particularly to things that we will deal with in the committee stage-particularly the Australian Democrats' amendments, although I will make some comments about them-but there are some points to which I wish to respond.

A general point by Senator Watson about the nature of these omnibus Bills was that we bring together a lot of disparate elements of tax reform in one Bill, and this sometimes holds up desirable changes within it-in this particular example, the proposal to reduce the tax rates. From the Government's point of view, the problem with suggesting that, rather than having an omnibus Bill, we could have a series of smaller, more specific Bills dealing with identified separate areas, is that I do not think we could get a guarantee that the total amount of debating time taken up in debating four or five-or even two-separate Bills, if we broke the omnibus Bill into more than one, would not be greater than the amount we spend on the omnibus legislation. We would achieve the same outcome at greater cost.

I do not mind there being more debate if it means that more issues are discussed-there is greater opportunity for the Senate properly to review legislation that comes before it-but what we would get from some of Senator Watson's colleagues, from time to time, would be simply greater length of debate but not greater depth. I think that that is a problem that makes us reluctant in the first instance to try to change the manner in which these matters are brought before an already crowded Senate legislative program.

In fact, I think the omnibus Bill process, provided we keep some limit on the size of them and we keep enough Bills coming through to keep up a flow of amendments, does facilitate the joint objectives of keeping the legislative program flowing through the Senate so that we can get the body of legislation we are seeking passed, while keeping the debate manageable. I think the speeches during the second reading debate on this occasion have indicated that. People have managed to traverse the field of all the matters in this Bill. In fact, some of them have managed to traverse a few things that are not in this Bill, and I will come back to that in a moment. I do not object to that; it was an opportunity to talk about tax generally and it was taken up. It is our current intention to continue to pursue taxation laws amendment Bills of the type that we have before us, and I expect there to be more.

I do not want to pursue at this stage the interesting debate that Senator Watson raised-and it is not dissimilar to one he raised before-about section 53 and the greater powers to the Senate to amend. There has been some discussion on that in this place before. We have had opinions presented about the powers of the Senate to amend these matters, what imposing a burden means and all of these sorts of very interesting questions.

The Clerk has outlined ably what the traditional interpretation of that matter is. I think it may be that it is a question we need to have a more contemporary examination of, but I do not want to do it on the run in this particular Bill. I am happy to have a continuing discussion about that with Senator Watson and others.

There is one other general point I should make about the manner of administration of the changes to the rates that came into effect on 1 January and the concerns that have been expressed about the fact that the schedules have been changed and, therefore, the rate at which deductions are being made is in a schedule predicated on these changes. In some way there is a concern that this is, in effect, legislation by regulation. But of course-and I know that Senate Watson is fully aware of this-nothing in those regulations or schedules in any way changes the tax obligation of the individual taxpayer over the financial year. Taxpayers' obligations are determined by the legislation, and properly so.

I think it is quite sensible and appropriate administratively for those schedules so to reflect those changes and I do not think it is a procedural problem that we need to dwell upon-although the capacity of the Senate to receive and to pass legislation expeditiously on the rates is a proper point to raise. I would certainly have been happier had we been in a position to pass it last year, and we discussed that, but the arrangements to facilitate that could not be agreed upon. I acknowledge the general point, but I do not want to spend any more time on it. I am absolutely confident that the procedure is proper and sound, although if the Senate were able to make arrangements to pass such Bills more expeditiously in the future that would be desirable.

I do not want to talk much about the amendments that Senate Spindler has brought forward because we will get the chance to do that in the committee stage and I will do it then. In the second reading stage I will talk about the approach to the general question of taxation legislation that those amendments portray, without going to the detail of each of them because I will do that in turn in the committee stage.

Once again, the Democrat amendments reflect a lack of strategic approach. The overall approach that these amendments reflect is one to which I have referred before in this chamber as a bower bird theory of tax amendment-that is, one hops around looking for all of the bright shiny bits, picks them up and tries to drop them into the tax Act, without looking at what the aggregate impact of those suggested changes might be. Some of the individual bits are quite bright and shiny; some of the problems with which Senator Spindler is trying to deal are very annoying. It is annoying that sometimes people deliberately hold their conferences overseas so that they can get an overseas trip at the taxpayers' expense. They do do that, and it annoys the hell out of me and most Australian taxpayers. But trying to deal with that in the way that Senator Spindler does has more shortcomings than benefits. I will deal with the detail of this in the committee stage.

I am simply saying that we cannot hop around and say, `Here is a populist little message; the public is annoyed about this'. Knowing that no party which aspires to govern the country could ever support the amendments as put forward, the Democrats say, `We will be able to say to the people who are concerned that we tried to amend it and those terrible major parties conspired against us and would not vote for it'. The corollary is not that they have to put forward an overall considered program for tax reform; the Democrats do not have to think through all of the implications of the proposals that they are putting forward because they have the luxury of knowing that they will never have to implement them.

Whilst the underlying problems to which some of these amendments relate are real and the cause of annoyance to many individual Australians and to many members of this chamber-including myself-I do not think the proposals deal sensibly with those problems. We are not going to get very far if we continue to concentrate upon isolated attempts to pick up popular causes without an integrated strategic approach to the question of taxes overall.

Before I turn to the consistent theme in the speeches of Senators Panizza and Crane about sales tax and a goods and services tax-which did not really relate to the Bill so I will not spend much time talking about it-perhaps they will allow me, for a minute or two, to share their indulgence on this question of the length of the tax legislation, its complexity and the much vaunted issue of making the income tax system simpler. I am not absolutely sure that I think `simplicity'-as much as it is one of the traditional objectives of tax policy along with equity and efficiency-is a very appropriate word, but it is now the word that is in common parlance so let us continue to use it.

The honourable senators referred to two things which I think are appropriate objectives. The first is to make those tax laws that affect the activities of Australians, as taxpayers, more comprehensible to them-whether they are individual men and women on pay-as-you-earn (PAYE) with a little interest from the bank, or people running very complex corporate structures. The objective should be to make the tax laws more comprehensible to those people who have to comply with them as part of an overall strategy of encouraging people to comply voluntarily with their tax obligations. One feature of a move in that direction is to make it easier for people to understand what it is they have to do. It makes it less frustrating for them and it makes it less likely that they will give up in frustration.

The other side of that coin is to reduce the cost of compliance-the cost of running the tax system-on two counts. One is the cost of compliance for individuals and businesses-the costs that they incur in meeting the requirements of the tax Act-and the other is the cost of administration; the cost to the Government of administering the tax system which is, ultimately, a cost on those same taxpayers. Those two sides are the real objectives of simplicity. If the only objective is to have a simple tax system that would not be hard at all; one could say that everybody should pay a fair amount of tax and the Commissioner of Taxation should impose a levy that is fair on everybody. That is a very simple tax Act, but as soon as one started to administer it, it would, of course, be a nightmare and nobody would seriously propose that. I am simply saying that making the Act easy to read is not an objective in itself.

We will not get a `simple' tax system-according to the common, everyday use of that word-because we have a tax system that does, and will, need to continue to administer a very complex society in which people, for tax reasons but also for proper administrative business reasons, structure their affairs in very complex ways. Therefore, the tax system that operates within a modern complex economy will remain complex.

But it can be made simpler than it is. The so-called blue book on self-assessment is, I think, a substantial step forward to making it simpler for some taxpayers. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) announced very recently an initiative to try to make a very important area of the tax system simpler-that is, the area relating to superannuation. I think that is a proper priority because it is an area of the tax system that falls on individual PAYE taxpayers and others. Many people who have done their own tax returns all their lives-who have always filled in their tax returns at the appropriate time of the year and sent them off-find that as they retire they have an incomprehensible document before them and they do not know where to turn.

I think the broad question of simplification of the tax system is very easy to advocate, but it is very hard to do. However, it is a proper priority, which I share. When we then say that one of our objectives is to reduce compliance costs, we have people advocating a goods and services tax. That seems very strange to me, because on all of the evidence I have seen-including evidence from supporters of the consumption tax-it is acknowledged that the aggregate compliance costs for business of a broadly based consumption tax of whichever type, are higher than the compliance costs of a wholesale sales tax system.

I have not heard that that matter is the subject of debate. Professor Sandford, the British expert on compliance costs, who is a supporter of the introduction of a broadly based consumption tax, nevertheless says that one thing that has to be acknowledged about it is that it will make people put compliance costs up, and I believe that that is clearly and unquestionably correct. Therefore, we cannot have it both ways.

If those opposite are saying that they are looking for a system with lower compliance costs, they cannot then say, `and our solution to the problem is a broadly based consumption tax', because that flies in the face of that objective. If we look at the range of equity, efficiency and simplicity objectives of the tax system, the issue falls at the hurdles before we get to simplicity, because I am opposed to it on equity grounds. We will all have opportunities to debate the problems that it raises in terms of distribution, compensation and the equity problems that arise when and if those opposite get around to telling us what it is they are actually going to do.

I am simply saying that if they want to come here today and talk properly, as Senators Crane and Panizza have done, about the correct objective of reducing the cost of compliance in the tax system, they have to recognise that that is not what the broadly based consumption tax will do; it will increase compliance costs. Having diverted from the Bill no more than anybody else in this debate, I thank honourable senators for supporting it, and I will deal with the amendments when they arise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last year the Opposition was confronted with the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6) 1990, which has been reintroduced with amendments as the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill 1991. We were confronted with an omnibus Bill which we believed had a lot of imperfections. The question was how to deal with so many difficulties in so many areas given the short space of time available for debating Bills of a complex nature, how to get a semblance of understanding of the issues and, where there were difficulties, to ensure that we could overcome those difficulties by prompt legislative change. I therefore thank the Government for its assistance in resolving this difficult issue. The Opposition placed basically a minimum of 16 issues of concern with the Government by way of advance notice and the Government has responded in a very positive way.

SPEECH.PARA: We have a number of amendments, in many cases fully addressing the issues that we raised and, in some cases, addressing the issues perhaps not as comprehensively as we would have wished. On other matters we have been given an understanding that the Government intends to further examine the issues, some of which will be subject to legislative change in the future. We anxiously await those amendments at the earliest opportunity.

One of the difficulties that arise in amending previous legislation is the date of operation. In this mechanism of giving the Government some advance information, we saw an opportunity of bringing down significant amendments at the time of debating the Bill. This is important because, if we have different legislative operative dates-and a number of these matters have come back to the Senate for, I think, the third time-the people who originally complied with the legislation suddenly find that they are disadvantaged as a result of there being a fairer amendment because the date of the amendment does not always relate back to the original change. So when we have a succession of changes, each with a different amending date, there is something of a dilemma for those complying with changing laws.

I refer to one particular company in relation to internal asset transfers. This company accepted the legislation of the day and it did its internal reconstruction. It paid the various taxes, charges and stamp duties that applied, only to find that a subsequent amendment came through which made unnecessary the procedure that was mandatory through the legislation passed earlier. Honourable senators would understand, on the other hand, that the companies that did not take advantage of that situation at the time, or did not see the need to move so quickly, benefited as a result of waiting for the subsequent change. But we have to put ourselves in the position of those that complied with the law as it then was, not knowing at the time that there was a likelihood of change?

If I may, I will use the title of the Bill to respond to a couple of issues. I take a very simple view of this question of simplicity. Is this simplicity a belated acknowledgment by the Government of the need to restore a lot of taxpayers' rights which have been lost since 1983? We all recognise the need for simplicity, but the simplicity must essentially exist in those areas which affect the great bulk of taxpayers-the ordinary pay-as-you-earn (PAYE) taxpayers and the ordinary businessmen who have an uncomplicated tax business arrangement.

In these areas, I think it is mandatory for government to make the laws very much more simple than they are now. Perhaps Senator McMullan, when responding, might be good enough to tell me whether the Senate is likely to receive, in this session, the first of the simplification changes that were announced in the so-called blue book of December last year. I think the taxpaying community around Australia is anxiously looking forward to those simplification changes. We know that some of those changes require some sort of community debate and some feedback to the Australian Taxation Office, but I believe that the community is awaiting the first of those simplicity changes to the Act.

It is unfortunate that we are not moving towards simplification of the Act right now. There are a lot of complicating factors in this Bill and I agree with Senator McMullan that, in many aspects, businesses are becoming more technical, complex and international in character. In these areas we are not going to have a simple income tax Act. However, there could have been a better grouping, with more examples and more illustrations. Perhaps it could be internationalised so that a common set of understandings applies to situations both in Australia and overseas. I think it is unfortunate that people who come to Australia and operate here suddenly find themselves caught up in a tax system that does not run parallel to what they experienced overseas.

One difficulty is that so much of the increased responsibility has been thrown back onto taxpayers. My colleague in the other place, Mr Rocher, spoke about the need for a Bill of rights. This is all tied up in this question of simplicity and the cost of compliance.

I do welcome the Treasurer's new-found enthusiasm to try to simplify superannuation law. Unfortunately, a great opportunity was lost last year when the concessions that were available to the lower and middle income earners resulted in some amendments that were highly and unnecessarily complicated. I believe that superannuation is an area to which the Treasurer (Mr Keating) should give some priority. It is unsatisfactory when ordinary wage earners cannot really determine the concessional basis of the deductibility in relation to their contributions to superannuation schemes until well into the year. The method is so complicated that in nearly all cases the calculation will require taxpayers to go off to a tax agent. I believe that, in this area, taxpayers should not have to resort to the specialist advice of income tax professionals. The requirements should be self-explanatory and ordinary people should be able to complete their forms on the kitchen table fairly quickly.

The Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) raised the question of compliance. I believe that it is a debatable point. Mr Chairman, I hope that you will allow me some liberty in addressing this area. I did not have an earlier opportunity because the matter was only raised during the summing-up stage. The matter of compliance costs, the goods and services tax vis-a-vis the sales tax, is certainly open to some debate. A single turnover tax with minimum exemptions must have a very low overall compliance cost compared with the complexity of a sales tax, which is multi-rated, has definitional problems, classification problems and so on. Compliance costs is not just a question of signing the cheque at the end of the month; it is determining whether the goods fall into one of several categories. That will be the subject of a more comprehensive debate. I could not let the issue pass without the matter being challenged by our side of politics.

Clauses 1 to 9 generally cover issues resulting from the foreign income legislation. Again, it would have been more appropriate had this legislation been introduced at the time the Taxation Laws Amendment (Foreign Income) Bill 1990 was debated last year. This time gap in bringing forward amendments does leave uncertainties and misunderstandings in people's minds. There is a need to tighten up the presentation of the tax changes to ensure that they are comprehensively introduced to the Parliament rather than on a staggered basis. We have the difficulty of people meeting those requirements where there are different obligations over a set period of time.

In relation to clause 10, we certainly welcome the exemptions for certain pensions. Unfortunately, we again lose the opportunity for a degree of simplification. This question of calculation is not an easy area. It is a little like the deeming provisions coupled with bank transactions. For the first time, pensioners have been introduced to a whole series of complicated arrangements. They have to meet 100 points when changing their bank accounts in order to get the higher 10 per cent interest that is now available from certain banks in Australia so that they do not lose taxation benefits.

Pensioners are beset by a whole new range of problems. It is unfortunate that people in their twilight years, who have not had many dealings with banks and financial institutions, now find themselves beset by a new array of technical complications and uncertainties. I place on the record my concern on behalf of these thousands of pensioners and aged people who I believe are being put to a lot of unnecessary cost. The fact that they change their account from one type of savings account to another or to an investment account means that they have to meet a whole array of certain points requirements, and that is somewhat difficult for them.

I give an example to show how stupid the requirements can become. One bank manager, simply by reading a form, asked the father of a young girl when opening a school bank account, `Has your daughter got a driving licence because that is now worth 30 points?'. I raise that example because it is part of this ongoing need to simplify issues. While there is a tendency-and a proper one-to minimise the administrative costs to the Australian Taxation Office, I am very concerned about the added responsibilities and obligations that are now placed on taxpayers. I will address some of those issues later on in the committee stage.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 14, page 12, at end of proposed section 63D, add the following subsection:

The amendment is designed to strengthen the Government's provisions contained in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill which deal with bad debts incurred by foreign operations of Australian moneylenders. When a bad debt is formally written off, a tax deduction arises to the moneylender. Because the operations of branches in comparable tax countries have been exempt from tax since 1 June 1990, a problem arises with respect to bad loans which crystallise after 1 July 1990, the interest on which is subject to Australian tax prior to this date. The Government has decided to apportion the amount of the bad debt which qualifies for a tax deduction in Australia with reference to the amount of time the interest from the debt would have been taxable in Australia.

The examples in the explanatory memorandum on pages 52 and 53 clearly conceive of the transfer of a debt between branches of a moneylender. I am concerned that non-performing lenders' loans attached to branches located in comparable tax countries that would otherwise be written off will be transferred to branches in non-comparable countries or to Australia. When the debt is subsequently written off a higher tax deduction would be available in Australia. The amendment proposes to deem any such loan transfer as a scheme under the general anti-avoidance provisions of Part IVa of the Income Tax Assessment Act unless the Commissioner of Taxation is satisfied that the loan transfer did not occur for tax avoidance purposes.

Can Senator McMullan tell us whether there has been a change of administrative policy as to when the Taxation Office considers a debt to be bad. Considering that we are now in an era of self-assessment when penalties may apply, this is an area of uncertainty.

I appreciate that it is not an easy question to answer. Senator McMullan may wish to take it on notice. That may be the preferable way in which to handle the question. It is a matter of serious concern that there are now some cases where the Taxation Office is not accepting the past practice when a debt is bad, for example, when it is put into the hands of a collector, when it is uncollectable, when it has been outstanding for five months, and so on. SPEECH.PARA: As to the amendment that we have before us, every time one proposes anything that is designed to crack down more harshly on tax avoidance, our hearts warm to such a proposal a little because tax avoidance in the excesses of the previous periods and to the extent it continues now puts an unfair burden on other Australian taxpayers who do not have the desire or the opportunity to exploit the tax system.

However, that does not necessarily make every amendment that looks like it will crack down on tax avoidance something that we ought to put in every Bill that comes before us. This amendment seeks, in effect, to prevent a moneylender from transferring a loan that may need to be written off from a listed country, where it generates exempt income, to an unlisted country, where it generates assessable income and, therefore, might be able to obtain a tax deduction. For example, a loan situated in a listed country for four years could be transferred to another branch of the same legal entity in an unlisted country, held there for a year, and written off. Under the Government's proposed legislation, it is true that the taxpayer would obtain a deduction for 20 per cent of the bad debt in those circumstances, which is significantly different from, and addresses significantly, the problem we have now where a person could get a 100 per cent deduction.

The Democrats' amendment raises some problems from our point of view. It recognises only in the negative in terms of the reverse onus of proof. There might be a quite valid commercial reason for transferring loans between countries. Companies might be restructuring their business operations-for example, in response to political or economic instability in a particular country-or they might be trying to streamline their operations. They ought to be able to do that. To the extent that the restructuring affects where the bad debt-if I can use this phrase-resides, they will pay tax accordingly. That is what this clause will require them to do.

There is a major practical difficulty in determining the precise point, the precise time, at which a doubtful debt becomes bad. This goes to Senator Watson's point and it is a flaw in the Democrats' amendment. There would be significant debate about when, to use my example, in a five-year period, the debt might have become a bad debt. It may not be as simple and as straightforward as it seems. I think that the sorts of arrangements that are targeted here are likely to be caught up under Part IVa. I think that that is the more appropriate way to deal with them.

The fact that we are not having a proliferation of court cases under Part IVa is not necessarily a sign that it does not work. It is more likely, I would suggest, to be a sign that it does. The fact that one does not have to take initiatives to prosecute is more likely to be a sign that Part IVa is engendering enhanced compliance than that we are failing to use it in circumstances where appropriately we could.

I have not yet seen an indication where the administration of the Australian Taxation Office approaches a taxpayer, say arising from an audit, though not necessarily in those circumstances, and raises a concern about a particular procedure and says that part IVa will be invoked if he does not change his assessment and pay tax accordingly. If the person then complies, he is very unlikely to put out a press release saying, `I am only doing this because I was threatened with Part IVa'. That does not seem to me to be a very conceivable scenario. Obviously, I neither have, nor should have, the information under the tax Act to indicate-and if I did have the information, I would not be in a position to reveal it to the chamber-that any individual taxpayer might have had Part IVa invoked or threatened. I think that it is widely and properly regarded as an effective anti-avoidance measure.

To the extent that the sorts of transactions about which the Democrats are understandably concerned are tax avoidance transactions, people are liable to Part IVa now and are not effectively any more liable to Part IVaa under the Democrats' proposal. The Government's amendment, incorporated in the Bill, is a substantial improvement on the operation of the law as it stands and it ought to stand as it is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point is the most important. Fundamentally, we have changed the law to provide that income which was not previously taxable as Australian income is now taxable, and that is a very good thing. We are proposing that the standard tax law should apply to that, that is, expenditure incurred in earning income is deductible against that income. That is the law and always has been. We say that these provisions will enable that to continue to be the law. It was right that we should have extended the tax law to offshore income, but it remains the application of the standard taxation principles that expenditure incurred in earning income should be deductible against it.

It seems to me that one can have either principle. One can say that it is not assessable income and that one cannot deduct the expenditure incurred. That was the previous situation. It was worse. I did not support it, but at least it was consistent. The other principle is that it is Australian income. By previous legislation we deemed that income to be Australian. We are now saying that we will tax on the profit but not on the revenue and ignore the costs incurred in earning that money. That is not a sensible definition of income.

I do not believe that a sensible analyst with any understanding of the operation of any organisation, let alone just business or a business operating overseas, would think that people would charge overseas and do their research and development because they could get depreciation on their buildings over 40 years. The first of these amendments seeks to remove tax deductibility for the remaining advertising expenditure that is still legal for tobacco as well as all advertising for alcohol.
I can do no better than rest my case on the authority of the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, Peter Staples. I refer to the Minister's press statement of 6 March 1991 which states:
Drug abuse costs the Australian community more than $14.3 billion every year.

This was in fact the finding of a study undertaken by two senior economists for the National Campaign Against Drug Abuse which was released on that date by the Minister. The two academics carrying out the study from the Macquarie University and the Health Economics Department at the University of New South Wales, Mr David Collins and Helen Lapsley, have estimated the annual economic cost of tobacco use at more than $6.8 billion and the cost of alcohol abuse at over $6 billion. The cost of illicit drugs to the economy was estimated at nearly $1.5 billion. But we are not dealing with those today.

In his statement, the Minister stressed that the estimates by the researchers were based on the most conservative figures and wherever there was a range of costs they always adopted the lowest cost estimate. Mr Staples also adverted, seeing we are talking about taxation matters and the economy, to the effects on the economy of such a large amount of money which is simply going down the drain, and which we support by allowing tax deductibility for promotional expenses. I quote from the statement:

In terms of micro-economic reform, there is clearly much to be gained for the Australian economy and the community generally by focusing on the social and financial policies which determine the extent of cigarette use and alcohol abuse.

I believe that the case is well made. I shall not detain the Committee any longer. The Democrats believe strongly that we should not support promotional expenditure on advertising these products, which result in these massive costs to the Australian community, by allowing tax deductibility. My amendment seeks to remove that deductibility.

The second amendment seeks to remove tax deductibility for that part of incomes that is above $200,000. We were told that it is the politics of envy or jealousy to suggest that that would be a just measure. I draw the attention of the Committee to the fact that this is roughly eight times average weekly earnings. While certain high-fliers, certain banks and certain paper entrepreneurs may well find it advisable to pay salaries above $200,000, $500,000 or even above $1m, we consider that somewhat obscene when we are asking the workers of this country to abide by the accord and to moderate their claims for wage increases. We do not mind if people pay $500,000 or $1m or any other amount above $200,000. We just do not see why that should be encouraged by allowing the employer a tax deduction for the amount above $200,000. People who advocate that this should continue should look at the disparity in wealth and income that we have arrived at in Australia. I refer again, as I did yesterday, to an article by Richard Farmer headed `Wealth by Stealth'. He states:

Even within the top 20 per cent of income earners, the benefits of Labor's tax changes have not been felt by many. The top 5 per cent have grabbed all the extra income. Their share of the total after-tax cake is up from 10.6 per cent to 14.2 per cent, with the top one per cent accounting for 2.5 of those 3.6 percentage points.
He continues:

Given this massive redistribution, there are two surprises. The first is that the ACTU has been able to keep the wages accord in operation at all. For those earning $35,000 or less, and that was more than 80 per cent of tax payers in 1988-89, there must have been something obscene at watching what happened to executive salaries compared to their own.
I concur, and that is the reason we are pushing these amendments.

The third amendment seeks to remove tax deductibility for expenses of conferences held overseas by Australian companies or organisations. It does not attack legitimate expenses of people travelling overseas to acquire knowledge or information, to attend international conferences, to carry out research or to use sabbatical leave to increase their knowledge. It would indeed help if Senator Panizza and Senator Crane were a little more conversant with the facts of the amendment before they made such claims.

The only area that would be attacked by our amendment would be if an Australian organisation such as, say, the Australian Medical Association of New South Wales were to have its annual general meeting and conference in Hawaii. The question I am asking Senator Panizza is: why should he and Australian taxpayers support that sort of rort? Why should we pay for holidays overseas of people that can conduct their business equally well in Australia?
Senator Panizza interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I pick up the particular point that Senator Panizza raised that when one is at a conference one is in a position to do additional research and to acquire additional knowledge. I venture to say that, if a taxpayer can substantiate to the Commissioner of Taxation that, apart from attending to the business of the Australian organisation at the conference, he has carried out research or acquired knowledge or information which was essential for his business or profession, I believe that would be an allowable tax deductible expense. The Minister might like to clarify that point in his response.

SPEECH.PARA: I have dealt with the details of the three amendments. I would like to advert to some of the general points made in particular by the Minister who said, in effect, that we should not worry about individual amendments to the tax legislation. He said that that was simply gleaning in bits and pieces, like a bowerbird, all that glitters. He said that we should wait for the Government to introduce comprehensive tax reform. The question is: how long should we wait and why should we not attend to the individual items that come to our attention, either by constituents or because they are obvious areas of unjust operation of our taxation system? Why should we defer?

I recall that last year I moved amendments to remove sales tax from recycled plastic products as well as from wheelchairs and other equipment used by disabled people. The argument that the Minister gave me then was, `Well, we have to look at the industry statement; we have to consider our position; we have got to look at it in toto and we will do something in due course'. The net result of that procrastination is that disabled people still pay sales tax on items of equipment that they have to use. We are not supporting the recycling of plastic products by removing sales tax from them.

I pay tribute to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, who saw fit to move to agree to such an amendment to remove customs duty from wheelchairs and other items being used by disabled people. I pay tribute to his understanding of the need for such piecemeal reform. So what if it is piecemeal? So what if we see one particular item that needs to be rectified? Are we going to sit back and say, `No, we will allow whatever is wrong with the system to continue for another six months or another 12 months until we are ready to present an omnibus Bill that is two inches thick'? I believe that is not the approach that this Government should take. It is not an approach that the Australian Democrats are prepared to countenance.

I draw the Minister's attention to yet another item that Senator Bell mentioned recently. He has been asking tax authorities on numerous occasions why members of volunteer fire brigades are subject to fringe benefits. Why, when they receive no money for the work that they do-protecting the homes in their neighbourhood-do they have to pay fringe benefits tax for fireproof overalls that they receive, for instance? If we brought in an amendment like that, would the Minister also say, `This is too little an item to be worried about. We will leave it until we revise the whole tax legislation in two or three years time'? I believe it is almost an arrogant approach; I do not use that term in a personal sense, and I am sure that the Minister will not take it personally. But it is an arrogant approach for the Government to say, `Yes, we know there is something wrong, and thanks for drawing our attention to it. We agree with you, but, no, we are not going to do anything about it'. I believe it is a situation that we should not countenance.

I rather regret that Senator Watson, though obviously competent and conversant with tax legislation, does not accept, as we do, the responsibility to address such items-such reforms-which affect individual people. They are not big items, I agree, but they are nevertheless items that people have said are wrong; that people agree are wrong. Senator Watson has said, `Yes, I agree with you in substance but, no, we are not going to support you. We do not think it is the job of the Opposition to interfere with a government's financial or Budget strategy'. That is what Senator Watson told me last time when I talked to him about the sales tax on wheelchairs and recycled plastic items. I am afraid I have to ask Senator Watson why he is in the Senate. Is it simply to assist Senator McMullan to finetune taxation legislation, but not to address obvious items which require amendment? If the Opposition takes that view that it is not going to interfere with the Government's financial or Budget strategy, what is its purpose in being in this place?

TALK.START.PARA: —That's nonsense.

—Thank you. I will do so and I take your point. But what would the Australian Democrats do? Would they eliminate tax deductibility for motor vehicle expenses? —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. In view of ongoing allegations of impropriety against Brian Burke, now in the form of sworn testimony, why is the Government not acting in accordance with the convention that public officials in such circumstances should stand down, in this instance by recalling the ambassador from Ireland?
