—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I ask the Minister whether his attention has been drawn to a speech by the Opposition spokesperson on retirement incomes policy at a recent conference in Wollongong of major superannuation funds in which the spokesperson, Senator Alston, suggested that improvements made by the Government relating to trustees of superannuation funds would lead to a decline in standards of probity in the management of these funds. Can the Minister advise the Senate whether or not there is any substance to this suggestion?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, of course there is no substance to this allegation by Senator Alston. I might say that I had the pleasure, on invitation from the organiser of the conference, to address the conference the next day. The conference was still scandalised by the attempt-crude though it be-of Senator Alston to politicise the debate on superannuation. The hairy-chested interjector we know here collapsed into a Uriah Heap at the conference in the face of stern questioning from the floor.

ANSWER.PARA: The truth is that under our Administration, the Hawke Labor Government, superannuation cover is now a right of ordinary Australian working people. Indeed, since 1986 some 2.3 million extra Australians now have superannuation cover because of our support through the accord in achieving that principle as a principle of wage fixation in the national wage case of that year and their having access to that right through their awards. That is a quite significant achievement when one considers that ordinary working people in this country aspire to a dignified retirement.

In the past superannuation was something that applied to the elite managerial circle of companies more typically than it applied to ordinary working people in factories, plants, offices, mine sites and elsewhere where they were working in Australia. That right has brought with it a role for those people to serve as trustees on industry funds. It seems that the point of Senator Alston's complaint was that, because some people may have got there by being nominated from a union, somehow or other they lack probity or responsibility in managing those funds. That is an outrageous slur. It is an indication of the approach that the Opposition has to the rights of ordinary workers. Of course, that was rejected quite clearly by the participants in that conference, many of whom were actuaries, professional fund managers and others who have direct experience of the management of these funds.

The other point worth making is that I was questioned at that conference about a fund which has obviously been mismanaged. The interesting example of this fund is that it is in Western Australia. I will not name the company because it is said now that the company proposes to change the situation. But this was a fund in which the company went into receivership and the receivers, when they looked at the entitlements in the fund, found that the fund had been mismanaged as a cash box for the company rather than as a fund containing deferred income of workers. Since the fund had been run down the entitlements of workers that should have matured through that fund were not there. Here is the case of the mismanagement of the past in the private sector in the area that in my view was not properly regulated until we came along. It has nothing to do with a union fund but is an example of how superannuation funds in the past in some companies-certainly not all-were seen not as deferred pay but as a cash box to be raided by the companies where the directors of the company were often the same as the trustees of the fund and they appropriated the money for the needs of the company rather than for the interests of the beneficiaries of the funds.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Will the Minister investigate the circumstances in which $300,000 of cash in small denominations was collected from Rothwells by Brian Burke's private secretary, Brenda Brush, in a suitcase marked with the initials `BTB'-Mr Burke's full name is Mr Brian Thomas Burke-and paid into the leader's slush fund to determine whether Brian Burke is a fit and proper person to hold the high position of Ambassador to Ireland and the Holy See?

I have made it clear that neither I nor the Government are going to prejudge the findings of the Royal Commission. The presumption of innocence applies just as much before the Royal Commission as it does before any other tribunal. It remains totally inappropriate to draw prejudicial conclusions about anyone when only one side of the story has been heard and when findings have not yet been made by the Commission.

—If such an allegation were made otherwise than in the context of the currently proceeding Royal Commission, of course I would investigate it for the sorts of reasons that Senator Knowles has just indicated. But when the matter is properly before a royal commission in this way clearly it is this or other tribunals in which it is more appropriate that this matter be determined.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Industrial Relations. It relates to the compliance provisions of the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Act which have seen the naming in Parliament of those companies which have failed to comply in the past. Is the Minister able to advise whether there has been an improvement in the rate of compliance with the Act recently?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, there has been, as Senator West has rightfully pointed out, being a senator who has taken an avid interest in the important social reforms of this Government. In 1986 the Hawke Labor Government introduced the Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Act and that is an integral part of our program to increase and improve opportunities for women in the workplace in Australia. The Act does require that public and private employers comply with it by saying what the composition of their work force is and what strategies they are proposing to adopt to improve the opportunities for women. Therefore, the underlying theory of the Act is that employers should be encouraged to think about the problems and encouraged to answer the problems in the most appropriate way for them. The only sanction for not doing this is that those employers who are errant are named in Parliament.

ANSWER.PARA: On 7 November last I tabled the annual report of the Affirmative Action Agency which showed a pleasing 97 per cent compliance rate. Some 2,300 private firms complied with the Act, but some 75 firms were named as non-compliers. I can now say to the Senate that 26 of those 75 firms have complied and I think that does show that the sanction of having them named in the Parliament is effective and does encourage compliance.

One of those 26 firms, Suttons Investments Pty Ltd from New South Wales-the only company of all of the companies in this country which, for three years in a row, had been a militant non-complier-has now complied and it has now filed a report with the Affirmative Action Agency. Characteristically, the Suttons report shows that in that company women are concentrated in the lower paid menial jobs and that the executive positions are occupied exclusively by men.

The Affirmative Action Agency believes that the Suttons report shows that the company is mindful of that distortion and that it does now intend to address it. The Agency advises me that it now looks forward to an improvement in compliance, given that this, if you like, most extreme non-complier has now seen the error of its ways and is proposing to alter the situation.

Before I conclude this answer, I emphasise that I would be wrong to concentrate just on the negative aspects of this matter. In its report the Affirmative Action Agency announced the triple-A awards for companies which are best practice models in Australia for respecting the aspirations of women in the work force. The names of those companies always bear repeating as the model companies, and they are: Lend Lease, Westpac Banking Corporation, Esso Australia Ltd, Griffith University, Western Sydney University and Hewlett-Packard Australia Ltd.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —He interjects because he is a refugee from that period of conservative government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly agree with the view that one would have liked to have encouraged more industry involvement in the cooperative research centres, particularly in respect of how new centres or proposals were generated. Having said that, some 50 centres will be established by 1994-95. Some of them are extremely good in terms of their industry participation. —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. In light of the Defence Minister's speech at the National Press Club on 6 February concerning the need to control and reduce the conventional arms trade and his answer to a question from Senator Coates relating to AIDEX 91, which he responded to on 12 February, saying that he would look into the involvement of the Australian Government and the Department of Defence in the event, I ask the Minister whether he has now made a decision as to whether to withdraw Government support from this event, given that a signed letter of support with his photograph appears in the promotional brochure for this arms bazaar. If so, will he tell us what he has decided? I further ask what decisions were made with regard to changes to the policy underlying military export guidelines as a result of the meeting of the committee responsible for approving export applications which met on 13 March. Finally, I ask the Minister whether he is aware of media reports of a renewed arms race in the Middle East with pending orders from Arab states to the United States worth up to $30 billion? Given that this is the case, does the Australian Government propose to discuss measures to control military exports to the Middle East with the United States Government or any other government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Defence Minister has indicated, review is currently being undertaken within his Department concerning its involvement in AIDEX 91. At this stage I am advised that that review is continuing and a final decision is yet to be made. The AIDEX exhibition, as Senator Vallentine knows, is conducted by a private company and it is not scheduled to take place until November this year. Under those circumstances the Government does not regard finalisation of the review of any defence involvement as being a matter of pressing urgency.

ANSWER.PARA: On the question of the review of our defence export guidelines, both Senator Ray and I have indicated that they will be reviewed in the light of recent international developments, particularly the Gulf war. That remains the case. The matter was discussed recently by an interdepartmental committee. It will be the subject of further deliberations by that committee and, no doubt, by the Ministers immediately involved prior to any announcement that Senator Ray might make on that subject.

As to the last part of Senator Vallentine's question, I am aware of the interest of a number of Middle Eastern states in purchasing further supplies of arms from the United States. I cannot comment on the specific figure of $30 billion worth of pending orders. I do not know whether that is accurate. The Government has already spoken to a number of other governments, including that of the United States, about post-Gulf war arms control. These proposals for arms control are still in an early state of development. I simply say that the Australian Government would be wholly in favour of any means that may prove practicable to limit either the further arming or the rearming, as the case may be, of countries in the Middle East region.

Finally, I might just say that Australia, as Senator Vallentine should be aware, is a very active participant in all the principal forums which are addressing controls on both conventional and non-conventional arms and their delivery systems. The work that is going on has general application, apart from its particular application in the Middle East. I shall only list them, not talk about them. They include: first, the United Nations expert group on arms transfers which is currently looking particularly at conventional weapons and the possibility of an international register to guarantee a greater degree of transparency; secondly, various efforts that are being made, in which this Government is very prominent, to get a convention on chemical weapons into place; thirdly, the efforts that we are making in the area of nuclear non-proliferation, including vertical proliferation, through our enthusiasm for a comprehensive test ban; fourthly, the status we have as a party to the biological weapons convention and the active role we are playing in trying to bring other states to become parties to that convention; and, finally, our recent membership of the missile technology control regime where we again are playing a recent, but active, part in controlling further development of those systems, which obviously bear so much on arms delivery.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Was the huge sum of money raised by Brian Burke for the Hawke campaign in 1987 the reason he was appointed Ambassador to Ireland shortly thereafter?
—No. Mr Burke is a distinguished Australian in his own right, as should be amply evident from his performance throughout his public career.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. What were the special qualifications of Brian Burke for that particular post? Can the Minister spell them out for us?
—I have made it clear that Mr Burke is universally regarded as a distinguished Australian and a very successful Premier of the State of Western Australia.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I draw the Senate's attention to, and welcome, the recent release from imprisonment by the Appeal Court in London of a group of men who have become known as the Birmingham Six. I ask the Minister: bearing in mind that the Australian system of justice is a direct development of the British system, are there any lessons or consequences from this appeal decision and previous trials to Australia's legal system of justice? Will the Australian Government be adopting any special initiatives to monitor the royal commission set up by the British Government to investigate this apparent major miscarriage of justice that incarcerated six men in prison for 16 1/2 years for crimes the courts now accept they did not commit in the first place? Finally, I ask the Minister whether he is satisfied that no similar or like incident could occur within the legal system of Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator McKiernan for his question. I know that, as Irish Australian for the year, his concern in this matter stems from that passionate concern for justice which has characterised the Irish people over many generations. I am delighted to be able to acknowledge his recent selection to that status. Of course, I am also aware of the case of the Birmingham Six, where allegations of impropriety and perhaps criminality on the part of investigating officers, the police involved, have led the British Government to establish a royal commission into the criminal justice process in England and Wales, or perhaps in the whole of the United Kingdom-of that I am not sure.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that there are several lessons to be learnt from that exposure of the shortcomings of the investigation that was undertaken which led to the incarceration of the Birmingham Six. I suppose the first lesson we ought to take is that capital punishment should have no place in a criminal justice system. Criminal justice systems are quite fallible and, in this case, the Birmingham Six would certainly have been executed for what was alleged to be a terrible crime of murderous terrorism. It also reminds us of the fact that where we have those advocating the return of capital punishment in relation to most serious crimes, we have to be particularly on guard against the sorts of pressures that can be felt by police and, indeed, juries to bring alleged culprits to successful prosecution in these cases.

It is therefore very good that, on 2 October last year, the Australian Government was able to accede to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights second protocol which signified that Australia had abolished the death penalty and was part of the world community which made that one of its central tenets of civilised behaviour.

It is also the case that one has to take special steps to safeguard the criminal justice system from being distorted by perjury and other methods of fabrication of evidence by police officers, which appears to have been the case in that instance. In that respect, the Senate, perhaps as early as this afternoon, will be taking a very important step in ensuring that certainly in the case of Australian Federal Police investigations of serious fraud matters and drug trafficking offences of a most serious kind there will be a video recording made of the questioning of suspects, whether under arrest or not.

I believe that this will be an extremely important protection, both for the police against whom allegations of verballing might be made and particularly on behalf of those persons who might be subjected to questioning and who could have evidence fabricated against them by police officers who are being overzealous in the attempt to ensure that the suspect they have faces the court and is convicted. I believe that the Senate this afternoon will be taking a very important step to overcome some of the difficulties which have been revealed in the case of the Birmingham Six.

Indeed, only two or three weeks ago, in a majority judgment, 4 : 3, the High Court indicated that it would be unsafe now in Australia-and certainly the judge should warn the jury against this-to accept uncorroborated evidence of simply a written confession by a suspect. Therefore, the video taping that we are undertaking will be certainly in accord with the spirit of the decision of the High Court in that case.

Senator McKiernan finally asked whether I was satisfied that no similar incident could occur within the legal system of Australia. The answer is clearly no. As my friend and colleague Senator Collins will know from his strong advocacy in the Chamberlain case, we have an instance in Australia where certainly a decision by the court system was found to be not secure at all, largely because of the difficulty in relation to forensic evidence. Once again, had there been a death penalty in place, very clearly, Lindy Chamberlain would now be dead.

I believe that there are many lessons to be learnt. As for the question of whether we will keep an eye on the royal commission being established in the United Kingdom to look into the criminal justice system there, of course, we will but perhaps it may well be the case that the royal commission should examine Australian practice as it is developing and the protections that we are affording, both in the interests of those suspects who are taken in for questioning and in the interests of the police. I believe that the royal commission established in England could well learn from the Australian system how to erect safeguards to ensure that the terrible miscarriage of justice that occurred there does not recur.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

For instance, with respect to the Government's proposals to ensure that there is full and adequate disclosure of political parties' accounts, income, and expenses statements, there is widespread support in the community. In fact, that support even goes as far as the Leader of the Opposition, as far as he has stated to date.

ANSWER.PARA: The need for disclosure legislation has been established and reinforced by a number of inquiries throughout Australia over recent years. One has to look at comments made by Commissioner Roden and the Independent Commission Against Corruption in its report on corruption in northern New South Wales--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. Senator Vanstone asked a very direct question. The Minister is wandering off, as he did yesterday, and I ask you to call him to order and to tell him to answer the question.
—Order! I believe the Minister is answering the question. I am listening to the Minister.
—On the point about disclosure, Commissioner Roden said:

As I said yesterday, we are doing it in such a way that it enhances the democratic system.

Senator Vanstone mentioned the name of Mr Bob Hogg. At the same time we are taking this measure to ensure that the containment of costs of campaigning, by the prohibition of radio and television political advertising, has a very meaningful effect on the need for political parties to ensure that they are adequately funded by the corporate dollar.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who supports the ban?
—Order!

—I will conclude on this point. To this Government the evidence is there. We need to ensure that the costs of campaigning are reduced. This is a particular problem that was recognised by the joint standing Committee of this Parliament. We are responding to that particular social need.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I am almost in a state of disbelief that the Minister can say that his Government is about cleaning up politics and funding to parties, given the revelations in Western Australia over the last couple of days, but--
—Order! Ask the question, Senator Vanstone.

—My supplementary question is as follows. The Minister in relation to his proposal for a complete ban on political advertising was asked who specifically, apart from Bob Hogg and the Labor Party, was in favour of such a ban? As the Minister referred in his answer to the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, will he say whether any members of that Committee were in favour of a complete ban? Who is in favour of this complete ban apart from the Minister and Bob Hogg?
—I have already answered the question.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. In August last year Minister Beazley said that the clamour for competition in the telecommunications industry had to be tempered by the need to continue to support this essential manufacturing sector. Does the Minister still stand by his commitment to protect Australia's $3 billion telecommunications manufacturing industry from erosion in the aftermath of deregulation? In fact, is the Minister prepared to direct the new telecommunications carrier to purchase network equipment requirements from Australian-based technology suppliers who employ 12,000 Australians and invest locally in research and development?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to Senator Kernot's question is yes. I am pleased to be able to advise the Senate that the Minister has given me some advice to that end, that the Government does intend to enhance the current industry arrangements for the telecommunications industry. Both carriers will be free--
—To direct?
—Not to direct. Wait for the answer. Both carriers, as I was about to say, will be free to use any technology from around the world, but weight will be given--
—There is a lot of weight on your side.

—Well, the Government needs men of substance. Weight will be given to commitments to technology transfer, local research and development, local sources of equipment and exports of locally developed products in the carriers' licence agreements and in the selection process for the second carrier.

ANSWER.PARA: I have been advised by Mr Beazley that the proposed changes for the telecommunications industry will increase the size and scope--

TALK.START.PARA: —That sounds like a threat.

—No, it is a promise. The proposed changes will increase the size and scope of the telecommunications industry as a whole. We expect that much more of the increase will flow on to local manufacturing industry as a result, already proving that it can compete effectively in many areas with the best overseas companies.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. That sounds awfully like what they said in New Zealand. Is the Minister aware that two years ago 50 per cent of New Zealand's needs in telecommunications equipment were manufactured locally and that now it is just below 10 per cent? Can the Minister reassure workers that this same fate does not await them under Mr Beazley's master plan?

—I am quite happy to concede that I was not aware that that was awfully like what happened in New Zealand. I am providing the Senate with advice given to me by the Minister for Transport and Communications. I assure Senator Kernot that the commitments given by the Minister on behalf of the Government will be met and will lead to an enhanced role for the Australian telecommunications industry.

—I refer the Minister for Administrative Services to his plan to ban at all times any political advertising on radio and television by Australians and also to a statement he made yesterday in the Senate when he said that `government advertising will be subject to the same criteria'. Does this mean there will be no further taxpayer funded campaigns promoting the policies and image of the Government? How much will this save out of the Government's $232m a year Budget?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I made it very clear yesterday that, in terms of the general period between elections, government advertising would be subject to the same criteria and law as any other advertising. In an official election period, government advertising would be reduced even more to a very specific list of areas. That point should be stressed and reinforced because it is one of those points that the Opposition in its misinformation campaign out in the electorate, in press statements even released yesterday by Opposition senators, chooses not to accept-that the Government will provide for government advertising to be regulated in the same way as any other advertising.

ANSWER.PARA: In terms of savings, one cannot give those figures at this stage. But it is quite apparent that our main objective here is for the Government not to be put at an advantage over any other sector of the community. That is precisely why we are acting to ensure that the same provisions apply in both areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. If the Minister is going that route, how much would he save? From the answer he gave, it appears he would save nothing. Does this mean that moneys that would be saved would be directed into direct mail campaigns such as the letters Senator Richardson sent to pensioners?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must admit I have heard some enormously stupid and inane questions in this place, but that particular one takes the cake. It is stupid because I am asked to predict over the next 12, 24 or 36 months what sort of government advertising would or would not proceed as a result of this particular decision. Those decisions on advertising take place over those particular periods of time. We would also argue that, because decisions on funding are taken in two or three years' time and not now, the precise figure on government advertising cannot be produced. Anyone in this place with any degree of competence would understand that. But we get Senator Parer raising this sort of issue, this sort of dead cat in the ring.

ANSWER.PARA: We have made it clear right from the start that government advertising will be subject to the same criteria, the same regime, as every other advertising and that we will not provide an advantage for government in this area. That is a very clear and concise part of our proposal, but the Opposition has chosen, from day one, not to acknowledge or accept it. Opposition senators have even chosen, through press statements and correspondence issued by Mr Andrew Robb, their national director, to write to organisations out in the community saying that the Government is seizing an advantage for itself.

In closing, there are two direct impacts of that sort of misinformation campaign. First of all, it misrepresents the Government's position. It is totally dishonest. Secondly, it is an insult both to the people and community organisations to whom the Opposition is writing and to the whole general public in Australia. If the Opposition wants to be honest and decent about this and if it wants to approach this debate fairly, then it should acknowledge from day one the intention of the Government's proposal, which is to ensure that our advertising is regulated in the same way as everyone else's.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Social Security. Has the Minister seen a press release by Senator Alston claiming that the Department of Social Security (DSS) has difficulty retaining its staff? Is this correct? Can the Minister clarify the staffing position of his Department?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was a press release from Senator Alston and it did refer to `an average duration of staff tenure of 286 days'. That was to show how difficult it was to keep staff in Social Security. There is a bit of difficulty with that, of course-it is wrong.
—You provided the answer.

—Senator Alston misunderstood the answer given to him. He has a little difficulty in understanding these things and this is another example. He asked a question last September in the Estimates hearings about the duration of employment in regional offices for departmental officers who `completed spells of employment'. He was given an answer on that, and it is certainly 286 days for permanent officers and 76 days for temporary staff. But, of course, it does not include those who kept on working and it does not include those who moved to other regional offices and kept on working.

ANSWER.PARA: The truth is not 286 days but that the average length of service of permanent staff in my Department is 6.7 years. By the way, those figures are as at 20 March, which is only four days from the press release to which Senator Reynolds has referred. In regional offices it is a bit less, the average being 6.2 years-just a tad more than 286 days, I think one would have to say. As far as transfers and resignations are concerned, the DSS rates are more than comparable to other agencies. In 1989-90, only one per cent of staff in my Department transferred to other departments, compared with 1.9 per cent in Community Services and Health and 1.4 per cent in Employment, Education and Training and Defence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does that make you feel loved?

—I already feel pretty loved. I do not have a problem in that respect. Again with resignations, Social Security lost 5 per cent of total staff in 1989-90 compared with 5.2 per cent in Community Services and Health and 5.3 per cent in Defence. All I can say is that Senator Alston has once again got it lamentably wrong. The length of stay is greater by many multiples than what he suggested was true.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport. Can he give details of what agreement, if any, has been reached between the States and the Commonwealth for the establishment of the National Rail Freight Corporation (NRFC)? Further, if the Commonwealth through Australian National has less than 51 per cent equity in the proposed National Rail Freight Corporation, can the Minister give assurances that the National Rail Freight Corporation proposal will not be destroyed by petty State parochialism and rivalries?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister has provided me with the following information in response to Senator Schacht's question. The signing by all State and Territory leaders of a heads of agreement for the establishment of the National Rail Freight Corporation at the October 1990 Special Premiers Conference heralded an historic development in the revitalisation of Australia's rail industry. The establishment of the NRFC will provide a strong impetus to overall reform in the rail industry, and the land transport sector in general, and generate large benefits for the economies of each State and hence the national economy.

ANSWER.PARA: Progress towards implementation was considered by the council of Australian transport Ministers, the Australian Transport Advisory Council, on 5 April this year. At this meeting the Commonwealth indicated a willingness to make an equity contribution of $150m to establish the NRFC. Further work will be undertaken by a committee of officials to examine options for establishing the equity shares and funding of the NRFC. Transport Ministers will meet again in early May and the issues will also be considered at the next Special Premiers Conference.

In response to the last part of Senator Schacht's question about this initiative being destroyed by parochialism, I sincerely hope that it is not. But that prospect, of course, always remains. Only a week ago I had the pleasure of opening, jointly with the Northern Territory Attorney-General, Daryl Manzie, an Australian Securities Commission office in Darwin. It is this kind of joint Federal-State initiative-like the national rail freight initiative, the proposals in the Inter-State Commission's recommendations on road transport charges and the Australian Securities Commission's initiatives that were launched by the Federal Government-that we need to break down some of the inefficiencies in this country caused by the parochial attitudes engendered by entrenched attitudes on States rights. I certainly hope that that does not rear its head in this very important matter of a national rail freight corporation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. In view of the fact that it is some six months since the matter of the Ravenshoe sawmill was referred to the Attorney-General's Department, I ask the Minister: have any charges yet been brought in relation to the disappearance of $7.6m of Commonwealth money from the mill? If no charges have yet been brought, is it anticipated that anybody will be charged in the immediate future and, if so, when?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not believe that it would be appropriate for me to talk about whether or not somebody is about to be charged. I do not think that Ministers can do that. But I can give him a resume of what has occurred to date. Between June 1988 and April 1990, when the company went into receivership, the Government paid $7.5m under a loan and subsidy agreement worth $8m in net present value terms to Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd to retool its sawmill and maintain a work force of 40. The Minister wrote to the receivers on 19 June and 14 September 1990 to seek details of how that had been spent. Incomplete reports on the use of Commonwealth assistance were received from the receivers on 19 and 25 September. Information indicates that there is a question whether the loan and subsidy assistance had been applied in accordance with the agreement and on 16 October the Minister referred the matter to the Attorney-General. The Attorney-General's Department and the Minister's Department briefed senior counsel in December of last year. As a result of that, further information was sought from the receivers in January this year. When it became apparent in February that the receivers were unable to provide the information sought, the Minister's Department commissioned Price Waterhouse in Canberra to review the company's records. That report was received in early March and a copy sent to senior counsel.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister's Department wrote to the Director of Public Prosecutions on 20 February. This was followed on 8 March by reference to him of the Price Waterhouse Canberra review. Senior counsel advised his legal opinion to the Attorney-General's Department on 26 March this year and the Minister's Department, the Attorney-General's Department, the Australian Securities Commission and the Australian Federal Police are continuing to examine the legal issues.

So it would not be appropriate for me to comment further on that matter until those investigations are completed. Similarly, it would not be appropriate to release the information provided by the receivers, senior counsel, or Price Waterhouse because possible Commonwealth legal action might be prejudiced.

I understand that some recommendations on this matter will be going to the Attorney-General within a matter of days. I can assure Senator O'Chee and the Senate that we will endeavour to make that information public at the earliest possible opportunity.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer and it refers to the Government's child support scheme. Can the Minister advise the Senate of the average waiting period for receipt of payment and of the collection rate of that scheme?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Zakharov gave me notice of this question as it involves detailed matters of which I was unaware. Ninety-five per cent of the applications for registration and assessment received by the Child Support Agency are processed within 28 days, and that is the objective of the Agency. In the few cases where there are delays, they are caused by the unavailability of relevant information-for example, a tax file number cannot be obtained for the liable parent or the relevant tax return may not have been lodged.

ANSWER.PARA: Early last year there were problems with delays in the Child Support Agency due to a lack of resources. The Government moved quickly to address this problem and backlogs were cleared by September 1990. A structural delay of eight weeks for the first payment to be made to the custodial parent through the child support scheme is due to the arrears method of payment. Child support which is assessed for the first month is not due until the seventh of the next month. The maintenance collected is deposited into the custodial parent's bank account on the first Wednesday of the following month. After this initial delay, payments are made on a regular monthly basis, provided that the non-custodial parent makes his or her payment.

The Child Support Agency has examined options for reducing this delay in receiving the first payment. No quick improvements can be identified while a basic tenet of the scheme-only paying out what is collected-remains. However, client dissatisfaction has been less obvious now that there is better understanding of the payment and disbursement cycle. Prior to the Government accepting the challenge of implementing the child support scheme, statistics indicated that approximately seven out of 10 people with liabilities to pay child maintenance failed to pay that maintenance at all, or if they did make payments they were irregular, both in amount and in time.

The Agency is successful in recovering over 70 per cent of liabilities registered for collection. This represents a significant turnaround compared with the pre-scheme collections. The Agency is currently collecting nearly $10m each month for the benefit of more than 135,000 children. Approximately 1,000 new registration applications are being processed each week.

Furthermore, I can also confirm that a report by the Australian and New Zealand Environment Council of September 1990 entitled, Reducing Greenhouse Gases-Options for Australia identifies Queensland as a State where solar hot water heating should be encouraged.

The Minister is aware of the potential effects of the white water rafting industry and will be considering it in the context of discussions with the Queensland Government. The Minister has informed me that she will consider the future of the Tully-Millstream proposal once she has had an opportunity to examine the task force report in detail and following appropriate consultations with the Queensland Government and the Wet Tropics Management Authority.

DEBATE.TITLE: ADVANCE TO THE MINISTER FOR FINANCE-MARCH 1991

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

Paper No. 4 concerns the Advance to the Minister for Finance for March 1991. It is a very interesting document. The Advance to the Minister for Finance is tabled each month. The March statement of the Advance is a more comprehensive statement than has been the case on many other occasions, in the sense that there are many more requests for usage of the Advance to the Minister for Finance than is normally the case. I do not wish to dwell on all of them, but I commend consideration of the details of the Advance generally to the Senate.

I wish to particularly draw to the attention of the Senate an application for funds from the Advance to the Minister for Finance for $2m to fund an increase in the Government's emergency relief program for 1990-91. That $2m is an increase on the original Budget appropriation of $7.6m and therefore represents an increase of 26 per cent.

The statement accompanying the request for this application of funds from the Advance to the Minister for Finance says that the reason for the request is `that there has been an unforeseen increase in the demand for emergency relief.' The growth in claimants stems mainly from recently unemployed people and low income families with mixed financial commitments.

These funds will provide additional emergency relief, particularly for agencies such as the Salvation Army, the Society of St Vincent de Paul and the Smith Family to distribute to people in financial crisis. The point I want to draw to the Senate's attention is the large increase in the requirement for this year. It is an unforeseen increase and is perhaps as stark an example as one could find of the human tragedy and misery that has been occasioned by the Government's economic policies which have led to the deepest recession that this nation has faced since the period of the Great Depression 60 years ago.

The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has told us time and again that he deliberately engineered this recession. Yet we find in the Advance to the Minister for Finance an unexpected, unforeseen demand for an additional 26 per cent of funds to go to those very important and valuable voluntary agencies that provide such wonderful support for people in crisis and destitution in our community. Whilst fully understanding and accepting this additional payment, it is in itself a stark indictment of the policies of this Government and of the human misery and tragedy that it has caused to so many countless thousands of Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for lunch I was addressing these three Australian Democrats amendments. Before I go any further, I have an explanation to make. Whilst addressing those three amendments, especially the first one on the selectivity of business deductions for promotional advertising or expenditure in respect to alcohol or tobacco, I said that it would be a very selective deduction. In other words, the thrust of this amendment is not to allow a deduction for promotional advertising of those products. In the part of my contribution to the debate about why that should not be, I said that other senators could come into this chamber and work on their pet subjects.

SPEECH.PARA: I suggested that Senator Harradine might use these methods in the issues that he takes up. He has taken exception to my reference to that. I did not mean to denigrate his work in this place or his ideas. Since he has been in this place, I have been somewhat of a supporter of his. If Senator Harradine refers to his correspondence, he will see that during the past 10 years I have written to him on various issues. I could quite easily have used, and could still use, other honourable senators as an example. For instance, Senator Calvert is a proponent of animal liberation and could quite easily ask to exclude the tax deduction for ammunition in kangaroo culling for the same reason. If Senator Harradine has taken exception I apologise, but my comment was in no way meant to bring him down in the eyes of the Senate.

I shall now summarise my objections to these three amendments. I have almost completed my comments as to the first. I believe that we cannot selectively address tax deductions for expenditure. If there are any social or moral reasons for attacking tobacco and alcohol, so be it. Senator Harradine was able to have an amendment passed to take away export incentives on videos involved in the pornography industry as a way of attacking that industry. When it comes to taxation, I believe that all assessable income should be treated in the same way, irrespective of whether it relates to alcohol, tobacco, pornography, animal culling or whatever.

I had partly addressed the $200,000 cap that the Australian Democrats suggested on deductibility of wages. As I said, it is a ridiculous suggestion, because employers being limited to that figure would restrict themselves to employing top management or experts to that salary level. That would cause people qualified to earn a much higher salary to go overseas to seek employment. Last night in the second reading debate Senator Spindler suggested that we should be doing everything to keep industry in Australia, to keep expertise in Australia, to keep technology in Australia and to keep business in Australia, and here he is with an amendment that will tend to send our top, highly qualified executives overseas.

I would also like to address the Democrats' fifth amendment, which relates to travelling expenses for conferences or seminars held overseas by totally Australian companies and attended totally by Australian people. I have probably said all that can be said against this amendment in the second reading debate. However, I will briefly go over my comments. I do not believe that we have a mortgage on all knowledge in Australia. I know what Senator Spindler is up to. He wants to prevent these conferences being held overseas so that Australian personnel attending them do not attend them as part of a holiday at the expense of the Australian taxpayer.

In that regard, the expense is not paid totally by the Australian taxpayer. The tax benefit would only be in direct proportion to a person's tax rate. If a person's nominal tax rate is 30 per cent, that is the rate at which a person can receive a tax deduction-not a 100 per cent refund. No-one receives a 100 per cent tax rebate. One may get a 100 per cent deduction, but the saving in tax is not 100 per cent. Unfortunately, some people seem to think that taxpayers using these mechanisms will receive 100 per cent of the amount that is spent on such a conference by way of a tax refund. They believe that if expenses of, say, $10,000 are tax deductible, that a total refund of $10,000 is received. That is not so. In effect, an amount of $10,000 is taken from that person's total taxable income. That is the difference.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are not a lot of PAYE taxpayers there.

—No, maybe not; but it is still the same principle. If a person gets a deduction from his taxable income, it does not mean that he saves that figure out of his own pocket. Even with a lack of intelligence on the Democrat benches-
—Order! Senator Panizza should address his remarks through the Chair.

—I do not mean to be disrespectful, Mr Chairman. If I speak in that direction I do not think I am being disrespectful to you. In future I will face you at all times. With the comments we get from the Democrats it is a bit hard not to turn around and let them have both barrels in the right direction. If a person reduces his taxable income by the amount that he claims, it certainly does not reflect totally what goes into his pocket.

SPEECH.PARA: There are other reasons, as I have mentioned, for holding conferences overseas. Not all conferences are held in Hawaii. If we held a conference in Hawaii, which is roughly halfway between Australia and America, we could get American experts who are not prepared to come all the way to Australia to go there and address the meeting. There could be something in Hawaii, or wherever, that people have to look at. For instance, there could be a hospital conference somewhere. I believe that Toronto, Canada, has the top hospital for mesothelioma in the world. I know that one of those conferences will be attended by Australians next year. There are other things to look at or to do. It is not just a case of sitting down discussing things around a table-or, as Senator Spindler said, having a holiday. There are reasons for doing this, such as special interests, special places and so on.

Because of the way interstate air fares have been and were before deregulation, it has been far cheaper to hold a conference overseas-for example, in Singapore-and fly people out of all of the capital cities in Australia to Singapore or wherever than to fly them from one capital city to another. That is what has led to this sort of thing. I cannot see that such an amendment is necessary. These conferences must continue if we want to get the experts from around the world to attend conferences run by Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on two of the amendments put forward by Senate Spindler. I wish to enlarge on what I said in my speech at the second reading stage and accept his invitation to rise on this occasion.
—You didn't have to.

—I know that I did not have to, but I have done so. He challenged me to read the amendments. I inform him that I read them very carefully. I refer to proposed clause 90b, relating to section 51 of the principal Act. Senator Spindler interjected, and talked about creating jobs for Australians, when I was making this and other points in my speech. I suggest that if a limitation of $200,000 were placed on tax deductibility, it could well, and I think almost certainly would, create a situation where we would in fact lose the best of Australia's top management because they would go offshore.
—Is that how shallow they are?

—Of course they would go offshore if we disadvantaged Australian companies; they would move away. The other point I made in my speech was that there are other ways of getting around this and it would not achieve the aims that the Democrats are endeavouring to achieve.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point I want to raise is in relation to proposed section 90c and the emphasis it places on Australian organisations. I think it is rather convenient and irresponsible that Senator Spindler uses as an example-I presume a hypothetical example-the New South Wales Australian Medical Association (AMA) going to Hawaii. In selecting that example, Senator Spindler insinuates that in fact the conference was a junket, an excuse for a holiday. I do not know whether the New South Wales AMA went to Hawaii, but certainly if it did, as my colleague Senator Panizza, who spoke before me, outlined, it could well open up the scope for that organisation to invite to Australia experts from other countries such as the United States, Canada and South America.
I want to deal with some realities that we have to face about Australian organisations. The amendment says:
. . . Australian organisation where that conference is held outside Australia.

I want to give a couple of examples of conferences that have been held outside Australia by Australian organisations. One was run by the Australian Wheat Board. It held a conference in Russia some two or three years ago when it was establishing certain aspects of the wheat industry and developing that industry. In particular, it was developing Australian trade in the production and sale of Australian made bread. At that conference, it assisted the Russians and other European countries in promoting our product.

Let us look at the meat industry. The Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation is the Australian organisation representing this industry. It seems to me that it would be very appropriate to hold a conference in Korea to promote the Australian product and to get expertise from other countries in the Asian area. Countries such as Thailand, China and Japan, to name just a few, could be involved in that. I would see holding a conference in Korea as being a very productive move. This would be in the interest of Australia and would assist in creating Australian jobs. It would assist in overcoming our country's current account problems.

The same sort of approach could be taken to the wool industry. Once again, it seems very appropriate to me that the Australian Wool Corporation, or any new body that is formed after that, should organise a conference on wool in a country such as China to promote and develop trade. This would assist that country and us in gaining expertise from other business interests around the world. It would assist us in developing our trade in China and promoting that product.

The consequences of this type of amendment with its blanket approach could in fact significantly disadvantage Australia in many areas. We can go further by looking at the consequences for Australian business organisations involved in marketing our products and developing our trade. As I said before, I think it is irresponsible to select the New South Wales AMA and insinuate that it is having a junket in Hawaii when the issue is far broader and far more important than that.

I particularly wanted to comment on Democrat amendments Nos. 4 and 5-I am not going to comment on the others because they have been covered-because, if adopted, they would have far- reaching ramifications. I sincerely hope, and believe, that they will not be. The ramifications involved in these types of broad amendments could and would seriously disadvantage the development of Australian trade and opportunities, which lead to Australian jobs and earnings coming back to this country, in many areas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to deal with several matters that have been raised on these three amendments. The first relates to the generalised comments made by Senator Spindler in responding to what I dubbed the bowerbird theory. Given that he so clearly incorrectly summarised what I have been trying to say-I know that he would not do so deliberately and must have misunderstood-let me be more explicit. I am referring to the fact that it is easy for minor parties and for parties that do not have responsibility for the consequences of that which they propose, or that do not have to administer the tax system, to hop about littering the tax Act and the tax system with things which look bright, glittery and attractive, but which have no significant impact or net disadvantage. It is simply another version of a problem which arises not infrequently in this place, and I must say in this instance it is certainly not exclusive to the Australian Democrats on this particular matter, and that is a failure to distinguish between talking about something that is important and doing something important. These three amendments are examples of that.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not doubt the worthwhileness of the objectives which people are seeking to pursue by these three amendments. In the instance of alcohol and tobacco they are dealing with subjects of great significance. The other matters are of minor moment in financial terms but are matters of some symbolic significance which annoy a number of people, not least myself. I make it clear that when I reject something today, as I have done in the past, because I think it looks attractive superficially but is of no substance or of insufficient substance, I am not saying that no small changes should be made to the Act and that we should wait for some mega-change to the Act. In fact, this Bill is a classic example of the fact that that is not the case because it is full of a large number of small changes to the Act. It is a big Bill, but it is essentially a Bill containing a number of small changes to the Act, all of which I think are appropriate. Indeed, the next Bill that is to come before the House and the sales tax Bills which will come before us in the course of this session will be similar.

In regard to the example chosen by Senator Spindler regarding people with disability, I have said that, although everybody is sympathetic with the need to provide greater assistance for those people, there are two points to be made. First, in my view, fiddling with the tax system is not the correct way to provide assistance for those people. The appropriate way for governments to assist people in need is to provide on-budget assistance. Secondly, on the last instance, I recall our discussing that the general principle is the point of significance. I am not sure that the greatest need for people with disabilities lies in the area of the purchase of motor vehicles. If a priority is being set for which area of assistance will be given, I am not sure that that would be it. Therefore, I am not sure that the amendment that was proposed on the previous occasion was appropriate.

I sometimes share with Senator Spindler the frustration resulting from the wheels of change turning very slowly. Things that I would like to see happen are initiated but, when the button is pressed, they take a long time to eventuate. It is not a question of in some way arrogantly saying, `Wait for us to fix it' and then doing nothing. In these instances they are not matters in which I believe anything is likely to be done or appropriately should be done through these sorts of amendments to the tax system although, in at least some instances, there are things about which I would like to see something done.

Amendment No. 3 concerning the advertising of tobacco and alcohol is a classic case of being seen to do something but in fact doing something that will have no effect at all. There are two measures available to government to do something about the consumption of cigarettes and alcohol. One, which is in my view the only one with a track record of having any significant impact, is to change the price-to put up the taxes. I notice that there is a move among the States to do that and I hope that they do. It is a great pity that one of the States is equivocating about that, and I hope that the Queensland Government changes its mind and supports the increase in taxes. It is a matter that the Federal Government has dealt with from time to time and may need to deal with again.

The most effective way of discouraging tobacco consumption is through the tax system, that is, by raising the price of the product, and not by fiddling around the edges. If we adopted Senator Spindler's amendment, I suspect that the price of a packet of cigarettes would not rise by 1c. I also happen to think that advertising tackles the symptom but not the problem. However, if one believes that advertising is the real problem-and I have no difficulty with it-we should do what we have done, which is restrict or, in the case of cigarettes, ban advertising in the areas over which we have jurisdiction. Those things are effective; they do something about the problem. They are not seen as a sort of Dr Feelgood measure.

Nobody in this Senate is more opposed to cigarette consumption or more concerned about its consequences than I. But that does not mean that any measure which talks about it and sticks one's tongue out at the cigarette companies will in some way have any impact at all. It will simply litter the tax system with inappropriate measures which have no beneficial impact.

Similarly, in the area of the restriction on salary or wage deductions, Senator Spindler is seeking to deal with a problem of real significance, although not great financial significance, to the tax system. It is very annoying sometimes to look at the annual reports of major reputable companies. I am not talking about the fly-by-nighters or some of the people who have recently been ripping-off companies to their own advantage; I am talking about reputable companies still operating efficiently in Australia. When one looks at the back of the annual reports where they have the schedule of salaries, one finds that, say, 50 or 100 executives in an Australian company have salaries higher than the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and whose salaries are rising much more quickly than average weekly earnings.

TALK.START.PARA: —Maybe the Prime Minister is underpaid.

—I think that is correct. Those salaries are rising much more quickly than average weekly earnings or any other reasonable measure. We have had a significant problem of a blow-out in executive salaries in Australia. There are those who say it has been led by the lawyers; that is not for me to say. The solution proposed by Senator Spindler is not unique: members of my own Party have raised it with me and publicly. It is worthy of some consideration, but I cannot see how it could be made to work.

SPEECH.PARA: Most major Australian companies-all of the ones that I am familiar with that have this sort of salary level involved-are what are known in the vernacular as group companies. There might be six or seven companies, and one would wind up either with an incredibly complex piece of legislation, having to track the employment record of every individual around the group company-and another chapter would be written for the tax Act for a revenue impact of about nothing-or with people still being paid, as some chief executives are, $850,000 to $1m; they would just get paid by seven companies instead of one.

That might annoy Senator Spindler; it might annoy me. But we are not here to feel better after we have done something. We are about impact, about outcomes, and I believe that what Senator Spindler is proposing will have no outcome other than possibly to increase the number of executive salary packages that come in the form of fringe benefits instead of wages and salaries or make more complex the mechanism by which executives get paid.

I do not see how we can draft something that will work. I have looked at the proposal. It is not simply just saying, `Ha, ha, there is a drafting error there; it will not work'. I have tried constructively to find a mechanism that will make it work-this is not the first time it has been raised with me-and I cannot find that mechanism. I do not think Senator Spindler can make that work in the way that he proposes.

There is a similar problem with regard to the denial of a deduction for certain overseas travel expenses. Some of the rip-offs that take place, which again in revenue terms are very minor, must annoy the hell out of many Australians who cannot afford to go on holidays or who, in the case of my constituents, have a big trip when they take the car and drive to Bateman's Bay. That is their holiday and, when they see their taxes subsidising people having a holiday in Hawaii, then of course it annoys them-and properly so. It is not one of the better features of our society that the most affluent in it believe that they have the right to be subsidised in their luxuries by those less affluent than themselves.

But the problem with this sort of proposal is that, firstly, it stands in the way of very worthwhile things that we would want to see happen. Let me just give honourable senators an example. There is an outfit in Western Australia called, I think, Pacrim which runs the Pacrim conferences. A Western Australian-based company, it is a successful outfit organising international conferences. It fits the criteria of the Democrats' amendment and it makes money organising conferences. The first successful Pacrim conference in Perth was a very big money-spinner for Australia. There have been two more, one in Hong Kong and one in San Francisco.

We would not have got everybody to come to the successful Perth conference if they had not known that subsequently such conferences would be held in other places around the Pacific. I hope the conference comes back to Australia quite soon. But if we tried to hold them all in Australia we would have 10 competitive Pacrims, one of them in Hong Kong, and we would be squeezed out of the market. Perth certainly is not the most centrally placed conference venue in the Pacific by definition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come off it.

—It is not even in the Pacific. My geography is that good. But this conference was successful and it was a useful initiative. There are Australian bodies that ought to hold conferences overseas because they are promoting Australia there. For example, if the Australian Institute of Petroleum Ltd or the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association held a conference in an Asian region it could well win a lot of business for Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: So the Democrats have the problem of what constitutes a conference and who the organiser is. There are loopholes galore in any proposal like this. Every smart accountant in every organisation involved would find them and we would still find the conferences that annoy both Senator Spindler and me going ahead. It would be an impediment-although not an insuperable problem-to legitimate activities that we wish to see taking place. It is a sledge-hammer to crack a walnut, and I accept that it is a very annoying little walnut. But the proposal will not achieve the Democrats' objective. It has a down side risk that is not worth taking, even if it were to achieve what is a very minor objective. I do not criticise the Democrats' intention in any of the three matters, but the vehicle is either ineffective or inappropriate. Therefore, the Government will not be supporting any of the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not detain the Committee long but I wish to rebut a couple of brief details. First of all, my reference to a hypothetical Australian Medical Association conference from New South Wales being held in Hawaii was just that-an entirely hypothetical one. It was not intended in any way to cast aspersions on a particular organisation; it was simply an example of the sorts of things that have happened.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point is that the issue is not whether certain things should be done or should not be done, but whether they should be supported and encouraged by taxpayers' funds. In all three amendments, as the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) has acknowledged-and I am grateful for that acknowledgment-there are worthwhile social objectives. We have two points here: firstly, we do not wish to use taxpayers' money; and, secondly, by removing a taxation advantage we seek to discourage certain behaviour. That does not seem to have been understood in all details.

I am encouraged by the Minister's statement that he appreciates and to a large extent agrees with the objectives that are behind these amendments. I believe that that opens up the way for some detailed consultation, which I will certainly seek with the Minister, to ensure that we achieve these objectives, if not by this specific means then by other means which can be developed after careful consultation and equally careful drafting.

That the amendments (Senator Spindler's) be agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to clause 98, transitional-provisional tax for 1990-91, and the discrimination that applies to provisional taxpayers by virtue of the Bill before the Senate. I remind the Senate that clause 93 provides as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that the amendments to the personal tax rates contained in this Bill for 1990-91 . . . will not be used in the calculation of the 1990-91 provisional tax. The rates of tax to be used in the 1990-91 provisional tax calculations are the rates announced in the February 1990 Economic Statement and subsequently declared for the 1990-91 year by the Taxation Laws Amendment (Rates and Provisional Tax) Act 1990. (Act No. 87).

I remind the Senate that on an income of $25,000 there is an extra payment of $96 by way of provisional tax by virtue of this discrimination. For most people in business the current period is, indeed, a difficult one with incomes slashed as the recession bites deeply into most sectors of the economy. The question of provisional tax and applications for variation weigh very heavily on people's minds and I think it is unfortunate that we have this additional imposition. I ask the Government whether, in the present circumstances, it is an appropriate time to review the penalties and the other arrangements that surround the question of applications to vary provisional tax assessments, because I believe such a change would be most welcome. I leave the matter to the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that was essentially a statement for the record which we will have a look at and consider. The distinction must be made between requirements under the provisional tax system for people to make payments at a particular time, and other changes which might in the circumstances affect the tax liability of taxpayers-that is, how much tax they have to pay. I think it is an important distinction to make that it may be that provisional taxpayers are paying a little more in the first instalment than otherwise might be the case, but the important question for all of us is how much tax we have to pay in a year.

SPEECH.PARA: There are some other points that Senator Watson raised towards the latter stage of his contribution which I will have a look at. They are not matters to which I want to make a detailed response now. I understand the significance of them and I will have a look at them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to raise with Senator McMullan a point along the same lines. He will find that in rural Australia there will probably be a record number of provisional readjustments this year. Senator Watson has covered penalties, but this is another point.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not remember what the tax uplift was last year except that the Government forgot it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ten per cent.

—It was 10 per cent last year. I think the Government forgot to bring in legislation until after a certain period, and there were some who did not pay an uplift at all, if I remember rightly. Considering the sort of depression we have in Australia-and one cannot call it anything but a depression-we are talking about businesses rather than pay-as-you- earn taxpayers, in other words, provisional taxpayers. Can Senator McMullan see any valid reason for continuing with an uplift in a declining economy?

SPEECH.PARA: The uplift was brought in originally because of the rising economy during the previous 10, 20 or however many years. I am not aware of how long the uplift has been in place, but I know it has been in a good while. I think it came in under the Fraser Government. The economy was expanding, and if a business was managed well it was doing the same. In a downward situation as we have now-and unfortunately for Australia it has been there for a while-why does the Government persist with an uplift? I thought it might consider bringing in a downlift.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should respond to that, although we are wandering a fair way from the Bill; so I will be brief. It is a bit rough to say that we forgot to bring in the Bill in circumstances where we introduced it and the Senate did not pass it. That is what happened in 1989, but let us not worry too much about that; I just thought I had better get the record straight.

SPEECH.PARA: The question of what, if any, uplift factor will operate in the next financial year is a sensible one which we will look at.
