TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. Clause 2, page 1, line 7, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:
2. This Act commences on the day on which it receives the Royal Assent.
2. Clause 3, pages 1 and 2, line 9 (page 1) to line 45 (page 2), omit the clause, substitute the following clause:
3. Section 50 of the Principal Act is repealed and the following sections substituted:
Mergers and other acquisitions

``50. (1) A corporation shall not acquire, directly or indirectly, any shares in the capital, or any assets, of a body corporate if the acquisition is likely to have the effect of substantially lessening competition in a market for goods or services.

(2) A body corporate that is related to, or associated with, a corporation must not acquire, directly or indirectly, any shares in the capital, or any assets, of any other body corporate if the acquisition is likely to have the effect of substantially lessening competition in a market for goods and services.

(3) A person other than a corporation shall not acquire, directly or indirectly, any shares in the capital, or any assets, of a corporation if the acquisition is likely to have the effect of substantially lessening competition in a market for goods or services.

(4) A corporation, body corporate or person shall not acquire directly or indirectly, any shares in the capital, or any assets of a body corporate if such an acquisition would substantially lessen competition in a market for goods and services unless:
(a) the corporation, body corporate or person has notified the Commission of its intention to acquire the shares or, as the case may be, assets; and
(b) the corporation, body corporate or person has provided to the Commission evidence that a net public benefit is likely to ensue from the acquisition; and
(c) the Commission is satisfied, on the evidence provided that a net public benefit is likely to ensue from the acquisition.
(5) Where the Commission is satisfied that a net public benefit is likely to arise from the acquisition, the Commission shall grant an authorisation for the acquisition to proceed.
(6) In this section a reference to a market for goods or services shall be construed as a reference to a substantial market for goods or services in Australia, in a State or in a Territory.

(7) Where a corporation, a body corporate, or a person has entered into a contract to acquire shares in the capital or assets of a body corporate the contract shall be deemed to be subject to a condition that the provisions of the contract relating to the acquisition shall not come into force unless and until the person has been granted an authorisation to acquire the shares or assets or a period of 30 days has elapsed from the date of notification in accordance with subsection (4).
(8) This section does not apply if, in the financial year immediately preceding the proposed acquisition, the turnover of the corporation to be acquired does not exceed $10 million.
Commission may investigate existing situation of market dominance
(a) a corporation, body corporate or person is in a position to dominate a market for goods or services; and
(b) a corporation, body corporate or person has made an application to the Commission claiming that they have suffered loss or damage as a result of that dominant position; and
(c) the Minister certifies that a prima facie situation of market dominance exists,
the Commission shall conduct an investigation in relation to the application to determine whether:
(d) a position of market dominance exists; and
(e) a net public benefit exists.

(2) An investigation for the purposes of subsection (1) shall include a preliminary hearing, at which the applicant and the corporation, body corporate or person proposing the acquisition must be given the opportunity to make submissions and to appear.

(3) At the conclusion of an investigation for the purposes of subsection (1), the Commission shall, by notice in writing, inform the applicant and the corporation, body corporate or person proposing the acquisition of its decision.

(4) Where a position of market dominance is established by the Commission and the Commission is satisfied that there is no net public benefit arising from the acquisition, the Commission may make application for divestiture in accordance with section 81.'.''.

The Australian Democrats have prepared a range of amendments to the Trade Practices Amendment Bill 1990. The amendments seek essentially to bring some reforms to the competition law in Australia which, in our view, are badly needed. The critical area is the criterion which is applied when an acquisition or a merger is proposed. The amendments I have moved seek to change the criterion that is being applied, from the current criterion of market dominance to one of substantially lessening competition. That is the criterion that was applied before 1977 and we seek to return to it.

Some supporting amendments round out the picture. Perhaps the most important provision is the requirement that notification be made whenever it is intended to proceed with a merger or acquisition where the target company has capital in excess of $10m and where a lessening of the competitive position is expected. Once that notification has been made, the Trade Practices Commission will have 30 days in which to decide whether the disadvantages of substantially lessening competition are outweighed by a net public benefit which could lie in greater efficiency attracting further business in this particular industry, or various other matters which lead to the need to rationalise a particular industry.

The amendments suggest further that these criteria should also be applied to current situations of market dominance and that, if it is found that the position of market dominance in a particular industry is not outweighed by public benefit, then divestiture would be available as one of the measures that the Commission could apply to the court for.

That is a brief outline of the amendments which have been circulated. I have taken note of the comments which were made yesterday; particularly those of Senator Austin Lewis, who stated that it was difficult for him and for the Opposition to have considered these types of amendments-which are fairly substantial-in the short space of time available. He complained that we did not give him enough time. I say, as a part defence at least, that the thrust of the amendments had been communicated to the Opposition and the Government before the recess-some three weeks ago.

However, it is true that the actual amendments have not been circulated until today and if either the Government or the Opposition takes umbrage at that there is a very clear remedy that I could suggest in general terms; and that is to provide the Australian Democrats with sufficient staff commensurate with the shadow portfolio responsibilities which they carry. My colleagues and I have responsibility for four, five or six portfolios each, yet we have the staff complement that is available to back bench senators with no portfolio responsibilities from the other parties. If we are going to have an efficient working of the Senate, I think this matter requires serious attention.

Let me return to the amendments before the Senate. In view of the far-reaching importance of the amendments and the Government's desire, which has been made clear to me, to address these matters in a way which gives sufficient time for consultation in the community and between the political parties, I understand that the Minister is prepared to support a reference to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, provided this reference includes terms of reference which specifically include all of these amendments, plus a broadening of the issues to the extent that other matters need to be discussed. I would flag my intention to seek leave to withdraw my amendments, but I will be interested to hear the Minister's statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —To ensure that we clearly understand the position, you are moving two amendments which are contained in a circulated document with a note on it, `10 April 1991 cw/664/spind'. You did mention nine amendments, but you are moving the two that are contained in that document?
—I think there are actually two amendments, which are the total contents of the three pages that were circulated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Spindler has been holding discussions with myself and with the Opposition leadership in the Senate with a view to ensuring that his concerns, which find some expression in the amendments that he has put into the chamber this afternoon, are dealt with in some appropriate parliamentary forum. I am glad he has acknowledged that the present consideration of the Trade Practices Amendment Bill is not an appropriate vehicle for considering the very substantial issues which would be raised in any considered deliberation on the amendments which the Australian Democrats have put forward. This is particularly so as they deal with the whole crux of the test which ought to be used in dealing with mergers and acquisitions in the Australian marketplace and whether the test should be that there is a substantial lessening of competition or that some real dominance results from the merger or acquisition.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that it is very pertinent to recall that on 12 March this year in his statement Building a Competitive Australia, the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, indicated his conviction that the trade practices legislation was our principal legislative weapon to ensure that consumers get the best deal from competition. There is no doubt that, if consumers are to derive the benefit of a more competitive Australia by being able to purchase goods and services at a lower price than would otherwise be the case, the vigilance of the Trade Practices Commission and the statutory foundation from which it works needs to be constantly under review and should be monitored by the Parliament.

Mr Hawke quite properly pointed out that there are many areas of the Australian economy today that are immune from that Act, for example, some Commonwealth enterprises, some State public sector business organisations and significant areas of the private sector, including the professions. For this reason, Mr Hawke has suggested to the Premiers that one of the main agenda items at the Premiers Conference on 12 May this year should be the whole question of the scope of a national framework of competition policy and law.

I hope that the Premiers are receptive to the initiative, taken in a very positive way by the Prime Minister, to ensure that the benefits of a more competitive Australia are enjoyed by consumers, particularly in areas where, at the present time, the writ of this Parliament as circumscribed by the Constitution and therefore of the Trade Practices Commission, does not reach. It will be interesting to see which State public sector businesses and significant areas of the private sector, including the professions, might be brought within the purview of the Trade Practices Commission as a result of those consult- ations.

It is rather opportune that concurrently with that particular examination by the Premiers Conference, this Parliament, through the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, might undertake an examination of some crucial areas in the statutory foundations, the very statutory framework, in which the Trade Practices Commission operates and under which it derives its authority to intervene in the marketplace on behalf of Australians.

I believe that the time that will be taken over the next few days, perhaps weeks, by the Opposition, the Government, the Democrats and those independent senators who wish to contribute, in deriving a set of terms of reference which encompasses the main concerns which underlie the amendments offered by the Democrats today, and perhaps some others which may be of importance, will be time well spent. This is an important area of micro-economic reform that is required to be undertaken in this case within the portfolio of the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy).

The Senate Committee will be well placed to call for written submissions, to hear witnesses and to canvass the issues in a very considered and deliberate way. The Attorney-General, with whom I have held discussions, has been undertaking discussions with colleagues as to the way in which a re-examination of the trade practices framework might be undertaken. He has indicated his support for the work of the Senate Committee, certainly as an alternative to rushing into a decision and voting on the sorts of amendments which were put forward by Senator Spindler this afternoon. It would require too hasty a judgment on these very important issues if senators on both sides of the chamber were called upon to make a judgment on these major issues without the benefit of the deliberations which might be forthcoming from a Senate committee consideration of a well-drawn set of terms of reference.

I support the Bill. I thank those senators who have spoken in support of the Bill and I indicate to Senator Spindler and to the Opposition that we look forward to taking part in drawing up the terms of reference for the consideration of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Spindler, by this mechanism of introducing an amendment and then withdrawing it, has brought to the attention of the Parliament the desire of the Australian Democrats that the subject matter of the dominant market test-the trade practices legislation-should be again looked at. In principle, we agree with that.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) reminded us last night that the House of Representatives, through one of its committees, has recently been looking at aspects of this law in relation to mergers and acquisitions, although I think it is some considerable time since the Senate has done so. It is an area in which I have had a long interest, being one of the areas of my postgraduate studies at the London School of Economics some years ago. I know only too well the difficulties in competition law and the many arguments that can be put as to the appropriateness of different tests.

One of the great difficulties is the question of the appropriate market. Australian business and industry are facing a very different environment to that which they faced, say, 10 or 20 years ago. Australia needs to become more international and what seemed to be an appropriate marketplace in many areas for assessing competition, which is something that we all want to encourage, may not simply be so today.

Australia now needs to have companies in many areas that are clearly internationally competitive. To be internationally competitive, they may need to be much more dominant within the Australian more limited marketplace than they have been in the past. We appreciate it to be an important but nevertheless complicated area of law, and one that is worthy of further consideration by the Parliament.

With regard to the most appropriate committee, as a former member of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, I understand its skills and record in relation to law reform. I am also aware of the enormous workload that it has had to undertake in recent times, particularly as a result of the changed procedures of the Senate which have resulted in many Bills being referred to it for limited inquiry. It has placed a great additional time obligation upon senators in that Committee.

I know, for example, that it was mentioned that Senator Lewis, who has a particular interest in this area of law reform, is not presently a member of that Committee. I am sure that he would want to contribute to a further parliamentary examination of this area of law reform. So that just brings to mind that it might be more appropriate to have some other body used in this instance.

Whilst I indicate our support for a review and further examination of these issues, I would like to have the opportunity to talk with my colleagues, senators on the other side of the chamber and the Australian Democrats as to what might be the most appropriate parliamentary Senate vehicle for that consideration. But, as I said, in principle, we support a further consideration of the issue and actually appreciate the fact that the Democrats at this last moment have decided not to press their amendment. It really does deal with much wider issues than those which the Bill is designed to cover.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Trusts (Hague Convention) Bill was referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for it to consider the question of whether the Government should be entering into the Hague Convention with reservations in relation to article 16 and article 22. We wanted the opportunity for senators to listen to the views of the acknowledged expert in Australia in this field, Professor Michael Pryles.

SPEECH.PARA: Professor Pryles played a significant part for the Government in relation to the conferences that dealt with the detail of this Convention. He seems to have played a part in the drafting of it as well as arguing the Government's case. It was of interest to us to determine whether it was his view, as the accepted expert, that it would be in the best interests of Australia that reservations be entered on these two controversial articles.

Professor Pryles gave evidence to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. Although he failed to convince the Government and the Australian Democrats that the reservation should be entered to article 16, he made it patent that such a reservation should be entered. I want to take the opportunity in this Committee debate in this chamber to reiterate our support for the position that Professor Pryles advocated, I thought most convincingly, before the Senate Standing Committee, particularly that a reservation should be entered to paragraph 16(2).

It was interesting that, when that issue was first put before the Rome convention, Australia opposed the second paragraph and the convention supported that opposition. The proposal to include that paragraph in relation to foreign mandatory laws was defeated. Subsequently, however, the matter was reopened on the basis of a French proposal and a majority was obtained. The Australian position was first to oppose it and was successful but, when the matter was reopened, Australia lost. Nevertheless the Australian Government now indicates to us that, despite the inclusion of the controversial second paragraph, it will not enter a reservation. Australia's opposition to that provision was consistent with the opposition of other common law countries, apart from the United States. In particular it was opposed by the United Kingdom. Professor Pryles told us that he spoke against it for Australia and the Canadians also supported the Australian point of view.

The issue is really one of certainty of law in relation to trusts. The second paragraph introduces something which is unknown in our trust law, that is, that the law of a third state, referred to in the article as `another state', may be taken into account in determining the appropriate law to be applied to a particular trust issue. In particular the paragraph says that if another state has a sufficiently close connection with a state, in exceptional circumstances effect may also be given to the rules of that state which are of the same character as mentioned in the preceding paragraph. That indicates a new uncertainty that will not enable those who settle trusts to determine with any certainty how those trusts as they might apply to property in third countries, for example, will be interpreted in future. Therefore, it seems to us that, in the interests of sound law interpretation, Australia should enter a reservation. I think that it is the case that Britain has done so.

The only argument for not doing so seems to have been that we want to encourage those states that do not recognise trust law to join in the convention and therefore to enter reservations maybe to give signals that are not encouraging. On balance, in our view, there is no doubt that when one balances the sending of a signal, which may or may not have some persuasive value-and there is no evidence that it is having any persuasive value-with seeking to maintain certainty in the interpretation of trust law, one must come down on the side of the latter. Therefore, we are astonished that the Government has decided that it will enter this convention, which we support in principle, but is not prepared to enter a reservation to article 16(2). I use this Committee stage again to urge the Government to reconsider its position. Perhaps the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) should again take the issue back to the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) and at least encourage him to read the evidence of the Government's acknowledged expert in this field who, as I said, has put a position strongly contrary to the position adopted by the Australian Government.

The second matter of controversy related to article 22. The first paragraph of the article provides that the convention applies to trusts regardless of the date on which they were created. Thus, it could be applied retrospectively, which causes us concern. The second paragraph provides that a contracting state may reserve the right not to apply the convention to trusts created before the date on which in relation to that state the convention enters into force. When one links that to article 16 and to the lack of certainty that occurs by the inclusion of article 16(2), one becomes particularly concerned. We find an instance of retrospective interpretation and the application of a law that may never have been thought to be applied by the parties to the trust. That in our mind is totally unsatisfactory. Therefore, the Australian Government should be taking the opportunity presented to it in article 22(2) and thus enter a reservation to that article. Therefore, in the instance of article 22 I also take this opportunity, at the last moment, to urge the Government to reconsider its position and, in the interests of certainty of legal interpretation in this country, to enter a reservation to that provision as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few brief comments. The Australian Democrats support the Trusts (Hague Convention) Bill without amendment, as became clear during the sittings of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. We do not believe that an issue arises on article 22 that requires any reservations. The decision on article 16 was a little more complex. We have carefully taken account of the arguments put forward by Professor Pryles. At the end of the Committee meeting I asked him where he stood, and he said that on balance he would prefer a reservation. I regret to say that on balance I came down on the other side, believing that certainty is not an all important virtue that overrides the necessity for flexibility and that we are faced with a situation where the world economy could create unforeseen circumstances and where deregulation has encouraged many people to use whatever legal mechanisms are available, including trusts in particular perhaps, to avoid taxes or to use international laws to their advantage.

SPEECH.PARA: In this particular case we feel that, rather than accept that the settler of a trust may at all times be the person to decide which law shall apply, it is good policy to enable a court to make the final decision. Article 16(2) is very careful in circumscribing the circumstances that would enable a court to do so. There must be a sufficiently close connection and it would only happen in exceptional circumstances. We believe that this formulation is preferable to a certainty which might in some cases be wrong. Accordingly, the Democrats support the Bill as it stands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government thanks those senators who have indicated their support for this very important Bill, the Trusts (Hague) Convention Bill, which will enable trusts-which are a very well known feature of common law countries-to be recognised and the property, the subject of the trust, therefore, to be protected in several law jurisdictions, mainly, in continental Europe.

SPEECH.PARA: We think that this is a most important international agreement-known as the `Hague Convention'-that has been reached in relation to this particular matter. We believe that it will be of continuing importance to those Australians who enter into or who are the beneficiaries of trusts where the property is situated in a country which does not, in its normal legal operations, recognise the trust idea at all and is quite unfamiliar with the way in which trusts operate.

So we think this is a most important protection being afforded to Australians who may be the beneficiaries of trust arrangements where the property is held elsewhere. For that reason, we prefer the general Australian Government principle of not seeking to make reservations but seeking, as far as possible, to rely on a treaty practice which says that if a convention or treaty has been devised in an international forum where we have played a very major role we should ratify on the basis of the text agreed to at that particular international forum rather than make reservations.

Of course, we could make reservations-that is our sovereign right-in relation to article 16(2). But it is even more important to recall the history of the drawing of this particular article where, in relation to that second paragraph, which was inserted at the insistence of several law jurisdictions, Australia argued for and obtained the inclusion of the phrase `in exceptional circumstances'. Because Australia actually tried to limit the way in which the court might exercise the discretion conferred in that paragraph and played, in other words, a very full and effective role in the drawing of the actual words of that particular paragraph, I think it would now be somewhat churlish of Australia to say to those countries with which negotiations were conducted, `Having achieved some modification and narrowed the operation of that second paragraph of article 16, we are now going to make a reservation on the whole of that paragraph anyway'. That would be somewhat churlish.

Australia will have a much better chance of arguing in favour of several certain law countries ratifying this particular convention if we can say that we, certainly on our part, have acted in absolute good faith in the negotiations and in our ratification of this particular convention. Therefore, the Government accepts the determination of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs that there ought not to be a reservation in this particular circumstance.

So far as the possibility of a reservation being made to article 22 is concerned, Professor Pryles pointed out that in fact the retrospectivity in this particular case would apply to the benefit of the operation of Australian trusts overseas in several law jurisdictions-and other jurisdictions, for that matter-in so far as the convention would apply very well regarded rules in international law, choice of law rules, to trusts regardless of the date on which they were created, and in that way the trusts would be given a protection even if they were created before the convention was itself brought into being. In that particular case, we have a very beneficial instance of retrospectivity operating in a way which is to the benefit of those Australians who may be able to take advantage of this particular convention should it be ratified by the nation in which the trust property, for example, is situated.

For all those reasons, the Government thanks those senators who have indicated their support for the Bill. It will pass. Obviously, there is no amendment offered, but I indicate that the Government will not be exercising any executive discretion to make reservations on the convention when it does ratify it.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a few general comments-and I think I can make them under clauses 1 and 2. They are comments I would have made on a motion that the report of the Committee be adopted. But I do not get the opportunity to do that because the Senate has decided to proceed by the alternative mechanism of putting the amendments in this chamber rather than simply adopting the report of the Committee with the amendments that are included within it, or seeking to amend those amendments within the Committee report and adopting it then. I therefore take this opportunity to say a few words about those amendments on which we were unsuccessful in the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: I do that in an effort now to save time. Under this alternative procedure, we could of course move those amendments again here, but that would be, to use a word Senator Tate used a moment ago, a little churlish. In a spirit of goodwill, we will not do that, but I do want to make the point that may not otherwise come through the debate in the Committee stage, and that is that the principal issue of the Crimes (Investigation of Commonwealth Offences) Amendment Bill 1991, which was referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, was debated at great length and with the benefit of a considerable number of expert witnesses.

That principal issue was whether upon arrest there should be a time restraint of a fixed number of hours in which police could question the person arrested or, alternatively, whether there should be provisions in the Bill that the period of questioning should be for a reasonable time. The Government's legislation provides for a fixed period of four hours with some provision for an application to be made for extension, except in the case of Aboriginal and young people, in which it provides a maximum period of two hours for questioning.

At the end of this long debate in the Standing Committee, which took place on three or four separate occasions, we moved our amendment that the position in the Bill be changed to provide the alternative of a reasonable period of questioning. That was defeated by the Government and the Australian Democrats joining together and supporting the original provision. Nevertheless, it is our view, which we hold even more firmly as a result of the detailed consideration of the issue by the Standing Committee, that the inclusion of a reasonable time provision would provide for better legislation than that which has come back to this chamber.

The main groups which have supported the four-hour limit are academics and civil liberties groups. Whereas these groups are obviously well-intentioned, in our opinion and on the evidence that was put before the Standing Committee, their concerns about what they saw as a more loosely defined reasonable time have simply not been borne out in practice. The common law is to the effect that after arrest a person must be brought as soon as practicable to be charged and therefore there is not an opportunity for further questioning after arrest by the police. That, one would have thought, from the point of view of civil liberties groups, would have provided for a greater protection than in fact is the case under the Government's Bill. However, they did not seem to address it on that basis and in fact they thought that there was greater security in providing for a fixed period of questioning after arrest.

With respect to those who put that view, I think it is wrong. Common law was held in the High Court case of Williams in 1986 and, as I said a moment ago, there is no power for police to detain a person who is suspected of having committed a crime for the purpose of questioning that person or for completing an investigation. The common law requires that the person, once arrested, be brought before a magistrate as soon as is reasonably practicable to decide the question of remand or bail.

Two of the judges in the Williams case expressed concern that the common law might not achieve a proper balance between the competing public interests of law enforcement and individual liberty. However, two other judges pointed out that the law relating to the powers of arrest assumes that at the time of arrest police have sufficient information to lay the appropriate charges. The question of policy, as much as it is appropriate for judges to comment upon that, seems to be an issue upon which judges at that highest level have different views.

It is our opinion that the common law does not provide a proper balance of community interests. Thus, we are supporting legislation to prescribe a period in which the police can question after arrest. Thus, as I said, we are supporting the concept of legislation in this area and we will, at the end of this committee stage debate, be supporting the Bill. But our difference with the Government is in what is the most appropriate period for which that questioning is to take place.

We support the police having a power to detain arrested persons prior to charging them for the purposes of questioning and for carrying out further investigations. However, I stress that this is not the same as a power to arrest persons solely for the purpose of questioning, and there was much debate on that issue within the Senate Standing Committee. Seven Government amendments were ultimately put and agreed to by all of us, which makes it much clearer. The provisions in the Bill apply only to a person who has been legally arrested. For that reason alone the Committee hearing was well worthwhile. It overcomes the concern that was put to the Committee by Mr Merkel, QC, who was interpreting the Bill otherwise and in fact believed that it was giving a power to question without arrest. That is simply not so and any doubt about it is now removed by the new Government amendments which were accepted yesterday.

In response to the issues raised in the Williams case, the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) introduced this Bill, which will provide for a fixed time pre-charge detention period. The question of whether police should have the power to question arrested persons prior to charging and, if so, under what restraints, has been the subject of numerous inquiries over recent years. I might briefly mention a few of those inquiries.

The first is the Phillips committee. In 1984 that committee, chaired by the then Victorian Director of Public Prosecutions and subsequently Mr Justice Phillips, now head of the National Crime Authority, recommended that a six-hour pre-charge detention period be prescribed to allow questioning and further investigation. This recommendation was implemented through changes to section 460 of the Crimes Act 1958 in Victoria, those amendments being made in 1984. No extension could be made to the six-hour period without the consent of the arrested person.

There then followed the Coldrey committee, which looked at the change that had been made in the Victorian law and found considerable disquiet among Victorian police and prosecuting authorities. As a result that committee, which was set up to review the situation, reported in 1986 that the fixed period was too inflexible and recommended that police should be required to take an arrested person before a magistrate within a reasonable time-which, of course, is the provision that we have argued should be included within this legislation.

The Coldrey committee found that the six-hour detention period had significant shortcomings. Most of these arguments apply equally, if not more so, in relation to a four-hour fixed period. It was inadequate in the case of complex investigations or where there were multiple offences. The necessity to apply for extensions of time disrupted the continuity of investigations. The six-hour period could easily be eroded by time lost in travelling, obtaining medical treatment or legal advice. In some cases it was simply not practicable to bring the suspect before a magistrate where, for example, he or she had been admitted to hospital. There was a risk that the upper time limit could be regarded as the norm and arrested persons might be detained for six hours where it was not necessary for the purposes of the particular investigation involved.

The Committee noted that, despite these shortcomings, a fixed time period adequately covered most interrogations and in fact 99.5 per cent of them were completed well within the six-hour period. However, as Mr Justice Phillips pointed out in his evidence to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, the police were able to persuade the Coldrey committee that there was a significant number of cases that might not be adequately dealt with within the framework. The Coldrey committee was sufficiently concerned about such cases to recommend amendments to the Victorian Crimes Act to prescribe a reasonable time-to apply the tests that we argue should be applied-with provision also for the exclusion of dead time, which we concede is included in this Government Bill.

The next committee to examine the issue was the Gibbs committee in its review of Commonwealth criminal law and, of course, this Bill is based on the recommendations of that committee. One important departure is that the Gibbs committee recommended that a six-hour limit apply in the case of serious offences and a four-hour limit in other cases. So not even in the case of the Gibbs committee was the Australian Government prepared to accept its recommendation of six hours, but has restricted it further to four hours.

The Gibbs committee concluded that it was desirable that police have power to detain arrested persons for the purposes of questioning. As I said, that is something which, on balance, we have decided to support. It recommended that once arrested a person ought to be brought before a magistrate as soon as practicable after the end of an investigation period, such period being six hours in the case of a serious offence and four hours in other cases.

The committee also gave a list of times which should be excluded as dead times in the calculation of the relevant time period. These included the time for transportation between the place of apprehension and the nearest police station; the time taken to communicate with a legal practitioner, friend, relative or guardian and the time taken by any such person to arrive at the police station; if an interpreter is arranged, the time taken for the interpreter to arrive; any time in which the person receives medical attention or when questioning is delayed because of the person's intoxication; any time during which an application for an extension of the investigation period is in progress; and any time taken to conduct an identification parade.

It was recommended that provision be made for an application to a magistrate for an extension of the investigation period to a total of 24 hours for serious offences which, of course, is far greater than the extended time period that is allowed for in this piece of legislation before us today.

The committee was of the view that an investigation period of less than six hours would not be worth while in the light of the Victorian experience. So the Gibbs committee, at least, has learned something from the Victorian experience even if this Australian Government has not.

The committee did not recommend a shorter period for Aboriginal persons or young people. However, it did recommend additional procedural safeguards for such persons. Again, the Australian Government has departed from the Gibbs committee recommendations in that regard.

I want also to refer briefly to the New South Wales Law Reform Commission's work in this area, and I might have to do so in a second bite at this exercise. The recent report of the New South Wales Law Reform Commission comes down in favour of a fixed four-hour pre-detention period. (Extension of time granted) In his evidence to the Senate Standing Committee the author of the report from the New South Wales Law Reform Commission, Professor Weisbrot, spoke of the Law Reform Commission's significant problems with the concept of reasonable time. The Commission felt that it would be appropriate to give a significant degree of statutory guidance as many police officers, it said, are young and/or inexperienced and would, therefore, benefit from legislative guidance rather than being required to exercise their own judgment.

The Commission was concerned that the only method of review is retrospective judicial exclusion of evidence. The Commission was also of the view that a reasonable time regime was too uncertain for the suspect.

Although these are valid arguments, the fixed time regime has many limitations which were emphasised by various witnesses in the context of the Senate Committee's examination of the Bill. The principal argument in favour of fixed time is that it increases certainty for police, arrested persons and legal advisers and ensures protection against unduly prolonged detentions. It also has the advantage that it is likely to reduce the amount of time spent in criminal trials in contesting the admissibility of material relating to confessions or admissions obtained during detention. It would enable there to be greater certainty in deciding whether or not a confession had been illegally obtained if the relevant time period had been exceeded.

However, a fixed time pre-charge detention is inflexible even allowing for the possibility of extending the period for up to a further eight hours. The representatives of the police at the Committee hearings were able to cite example after example of actual cases in which investigations, although taking more than the allowed four hours plus the eight-hour extension, did not go for an unreasonable time in the circumstances of those particular cases.

As I said earlier, the necessity to apply for an extension damages the continuity of the investigation period and may bring matters to the attention of the criminal community with undesirable results, such as the intimidation of witnesses or the destruction of evidence, as was submitted to the Committee by these police witnesses-experts within their field. Mr Justice Phillips also put to the Committee his concern that although the Bill provides for questioning for a reasonable time within the time constraint-in the case of this Bill four hours, in the case of the Victorian legislation six hours-what develops is a presumption that questioning for that maximum period of four hours or six hours is reasonable, and that is undesirable.

Mr Justice Phillips did not feel that the provision in proposed section 23c (4)-which says that the investigation period commences when the person is arrested, and ends at a time thereafter that is reasonable, having regard to all the circumstances-would solve the problem. The prosecutor could still tell the jury that in assessing the weight to be given to the accused person's assertion, it should take into account that the whole scenario occurred within the time frames specified in the legislation.

On the other hand, the test of reasonableness as assessed by a judge, which we advocate, has many advantages. It means that police investigations will not be hampered by a needlessly inflexible time limit, although the police will still be accountable before the court for the method and time of their interrogation. As I said, Mr Justice Phillips, from his experience of a six-hour investigation period in Victoria, supports the alternative of a reasonable period. As a judge, he found that disputes often arose as to when the period commenced, which question does not arise if a reasonable time regime applies.

The Opposition also has serious difficulty with the provisions which allow the shorter two-hour pre-charge detention for Aboriginal and young people. In relation to Aboriginals, the shorter interview time was strongly defended by the representative of the Central Australian Aboriginal Legal Aid Service-something we concede. However, we remain unconvinced that this sort of special provision is the most effective way of dealing with the problem. For one thing, it is a fundamental principle of Australian law and democracy that all citizens ought to be treated equally. If special provision is to be made for one group within our society, this surely discriminates against other vulnerable groups in our community which have not had such a provision made for them.

Clearly, however, if the reasonable time regime applied the problem simply would not arise. It would be a matter for the judge to determine what was a reasonable time for investigation in any particular circumstances, taking into account the special characteristics of the person involved, and that might be whether a person is Aboriginal, young or illiterate, or any other matter that seems relevant to the judge at the time-a much more flexible and a much better safeguard, we would submit. It must surely count for something that police are in favour of a reasonable time regime because, after all, they are the ones who will have to justify that their interrogation was reasonable in all the circumstances, and we should not discount the expertise and experience that they have in this area.

I must say in passing that I did think that the police witnesses who gave evidence before the Committee were particularly impressive. We believe that they have a legitimate and, in this instance, persuasive view. We were particularly disappointed that before this Senate inquiry the Government had not sought the views of the police from around the States, despite the interest that had been shown. In fact, the total lack of consultation with those people with interest in this legislation is something about which the Government should be particularly embarrassed. It is not as if there were any great urgency in relation to this legislation. It would have been commonsense to have consulted those people who have to operate under this new legislative regime. The failure of the Government to do so is, we believe, an indictment of its practice with regard to this particular piece of legislative work.

The Australian Federal Police Association, not surprisingly, was particularly critical of this aspect, as have been various police Ministers in their correspondence with the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee. Other law enforcement bodies were not given the courtesy of consultation either. It is also obvious that consistency of State and Federal laws in this area is vital: yet, as I said, the Government did not make any attempts to consult with the States. Now it seems that the State and Territory police forces will have to operate simultaneously under two separate regimes.

Many examples were given of the serious operational difficulties which will arise. Obviously, these issues can be resolved, but that is not the point; the point is that they could, and should, have been discussed before the legislation was introduced. In fact, it is fortunate that the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee hearings provided a forum through which the police could put forward their concerns. As I have said, it is totally unsatisfactory that they were not given an earlier opportunity to do so.

In conclusion, while the Opposition supports the basic thrust of the Bill, we can only condemn the way in which the Government has gone about introducing it in such a high-handed manner. We remain unconvinced, in light of the Victorian experience and the evidence from police representatives and others who appeared before the Senate Standing Committee, that fixed time periods for pre-charge detention are more appropriate than the reasonable time regime which we have advocated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, would like to take this opportunity to make a number of general comments on the Crimes (Investigation of Commonwealth Offences) Amendment Bill 1990 and to refer to those amendments of the Australian Democrats which were not accepted. It is a piece of legislation which we have subjected to considerable consultation and research.

SPEECH.PARA: On the question of whether it should be reasonable time, or a set time limit-in this Bill it is four hours plus eight, or two for certain disadvantaged sections of the population-during our period of consultation and research we in fact found that our position had moved. Initially we had adopted a position which was similar to the current situation in Victoria, which allows reasonable time, but we found that as we went and talked to people who were operating in the field-criminal lawyers, people who were represented through legal aid centres or Aboriginal legal centres; people who were particularly affected by this legislation-we found that there was sufficient evidence, rather than some of the anecdotal evidence that had been adduced by some of the witnesses, to show that in fact the four-hour limit for police was a generous limit.

I will mention briefly one piece of information which I think is very telling. During the preparation of the Coldrey report some statistics were collected in Victoria and it was found that in only 152 cases out of 42,000 did the police require more than six hours for the interrogation of the suspect-in these circumstances the person who had been arrested for the purpose of being charged with an offence. That is less than 0.5 per cent. I think in order to put that into perspective we need also to take note of the fact that at that time the six hours did not make any exclusions for so-called `dead' time, which is done in this particular Bill. It makes exclusion for a range of situations, such as obtaining legal representation, obtaining interpreters and so on.

The other factor which I think impinges critically on this issue is the fact that at the time when the statistics were being taken people who had been arrested were being interrogated and the results of the questions and answers were recorded in the time-honoured fashion-namely, by two-finger typing. Obviously, particularly in extended interrogations, this added a time element, which has now been removed in this particular Bill by the introduction of taping facilities which are mandatory, where practicable. I will return to the phrase `where practicable' in a minute.

In summary, we believe that the time limits offered to police for this particular purpose are more than adequate compared with the record of their work in previous years. We also believe it is necessary to take account of the position of the person who is being interrogated. In a democratic society we must start from the position that no-one should be deprived of his or her liberty without just cause. When we look at the police record in quite a number of areas-and I have only to refer to the recent Gundy matter and, similarly, to the numerous reports which we are receiving from the Royal Commission which is inquiring into deaths in custody-it brings it home very forcefully indeed that we must introduce as many safeguards as we possibly can for people who are not used to our system of legal administration. Clearly, it is a principle which applies to every person who comes into contact with our legal system and with our law enforcement officers.

I now turn to the specific amendments which the Australian Democrats sought to move but which were, regrettably, not accepted. The first amendment we sought to introduce would have allowed the person who was being given a caution to remain silent to repeat that caution in his or her own words to ensure that the import of it was fully understood. We believe the answer we received-that this danger of a person misunderstanding the meaning of the caution could be averted by the court subsequently being invited to look at the video or tape recording of interview-is inadequate. We believe that in our society a person who is being given a caution, which is an extremely important element in the subsequent legal proceedings, has a right to have a safeguard introduced to ensure that he or she understands it fully.

The same sort of amendment would seek to extend the categories of people, currently Aboriginal people and minors, who are given a two-hour limit. We want to extend it to people who are illiterate, people who are not fluent in English and people who are suffering from an intellectual disability. It has been argued in response that some of those people might require more time owing to their disability and that the time limit should be increased to more than two hours. However, that attitude does not take into account the pressure that is put on persons who culturally are unfamiliar with the way in which police officers in our legal system prosecute their task. We have received advice from people who are operating in the field that this psychological pressure can often lead to people being severely disadvantaged. I believe that we should take that into account on the grounds of civil liberties and plain humanity. I regret to say that these amendments have not been accepted. We will continue to monitor the effects of this legislation and we will seek to reintroduce the amendments if required.

The other issue that I believe is worth mentioning is that the Bill currently requires the recording of interviews where practicable. The Government has admitted that there may be many situations where recording equipment is not available. In that case, it is submitted that a written record should be sufficient. I would strongly disagree with that. While it is obviously and realistically the case that recording equipment may not be available on certain occasions, there is absolutely nothing to stop the law enforcement officers repeating the interview and having it recorded on the earliest possible occasion following the arrest of a person. I believe that the arguments that have been put forward in response to some of our other amendments are actually devalued by the Government's rejection of this particular amendment.

Subject to these comments, I put on record the Democrats support for the Bill as it stands and I also welcome the Government's amendments, which in some measure were in response to the evidence provided by witnesses during the committee hearings, particular by Mr Ron Merkel, QC. I believe that puts the position of the Democrats on record.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon in Question Time, I was asked about any lessons that Australia could learn from the fate of the Birmingham Six. That was a case where certain persons had been convicted of acts of murderous terrorism. It was decided some 16 years later, only a few weeks ago, that the police in the investigation of those terrible events had acted in a way which created a situation where one could no longer say with confidence that the Birmingham Six had been properly convicted.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been decided in the United Kingdom that a royal commission should be established to look at the process of the criminal justice system as it operates in that nation. I commented during Question Time that that royal commission would be able to learn a lot if it came to Australia to see, on the one hand, how we are tackling the sorts of problems which arise in the investigation of offences, where one has to balance the interests of the community in securing the detection and the eventual conviction of those who offend against our society by breaking the criminal law which has been established for the nation through the Parliament or in the various jurisdictions of the States around Australia and, on the other hand, the very real necessity to ensure that suspects are protected from undue zealotry on the part of investigating officers, which might lead to the fabrication of evidence as, for example, where the practice of verballing occurs and a purported confession is produced to a court, apparently and indeed signed by the accused person, but which has been put together by investigating officers and the suspect has been intimidated into signing it. I believe that this is now not at all a common or usual occurrence in Australia. The most important clause of this Bill is not so much what has been the cause of controversy-even in the committee stage of the Senate's consideration of this particular legislation-as the clause which provides for the taping of interviews of suspects, whether under arrest or not.

In relation to Australian Federal Police investigations into matters of serious fraud or drug traffic offences which warrant the most vigorous investigation and, one hopes, result, where appropriate, in the charging and successful prosecution of those perpetrators, the great virtue of this legislation is that it will be made clear that, in the investigation of those federal offences, unless the questioning of suspects and any confession or admission that might be made is recorded, it will not be admissible. Where it is reasonably practicable to tape-record the confession or admission, to quote from the Bill, that must certainly be done and the confession or admission will not be admissible unless it is.

So that is the basic structure of the Bill, which I think has not been given sufficient attention or weight. I think it will turn out to be a most important protection for the liberty of the subject. It will also prevent the series of accusations that is often levelled against the police during a trial that an accused person was verballed. It will now be absolutely clear to the court from its viewing of the videotape. Moneys have been provided in the last Budget for the Australian Federal Police to begin to establish videotaping facilities in the various States of Australia, in the Australian Capital Territory and in the Northern Territory. It will be very apparent to the court whether there was any overbearing of the suspect so that he or she signed under duress, or whether what is alleged to have been confessed was not, but was some sort of fabrication by the interviewing officers. I believe that that will be of great benefit to the police in establishing their integrity in the questioning process and it will save a lot of court time, which is also a further benefit of this particular provision.

The issue which took up the greatest time of the Committee was the question of what rights our society should confer on police officers when they wish to question a person after arresting that person but before charging him with any offence, the High Court having held that there was no common law power residing in police officers to question a person before having taken that person before a magistrate in the shortest practicable time, even when some period of questioning could clear the person who had been arrested. The Federal Government has effectively been required by the High Court to provide a rule which will govern the activities of those persons investigating federal offences nationwide, particularly the Australian Federal Police who operate in other States and Territories of Australia.

Quite frankly, it was not good enough to wait for the States to come to either a common view, which they have been unable to achieve, or a settled view even within a particular State: for example, Victoria and the way in which it has changed its legislation in this regard. We had to provide a rule for the Australian Federal Police, in particular, Australia-wide to overcome the difficulty revealed by the High Court decision. That has been done in a way which is very fair to the interests of both law enforcement agencies involved in the investigation of Commonwealth offences, in that time is provided for questioning of suspects after arrest but before they are charged. On the other hand, there is a recognition that the person arrested deserves certain protection-for example, that he or she has access to legal advice and an interview friend.
Of course, all the proper cautions must be provided. For example, under proposed section 23f:

. . . if a person is under arrest for a Commonwealth offence, an investigating official must, before starting to question the person, caution the person that he or she does not have to say or do anything, but that anything the person does say or do may be used in evidence.

It must also be made clear in a way which the person understands. Of course, the right to remain silent is not affected. The right of a person to refuse to answer questions or to participate in an investigation, except when required to do so by or under an Act, for example, is totally preserved. As always, the burden on the prosecution to prove the voluntariness of the admission made by the person is also noted and reaffirmed in this statute.

The treatment of persons under arrest is given particular attention. One aspect which is of absolute paramount importance to a person who is arrested and, admittedly, engaged voluntarily in helping the police in their investigation by perhaps admitting to the answering of some questions is that under this legislation both the suspect and the interviewing police officer know that at the expiration of four hours-and perhaps less if it would be reasonable to conclude the line of investigation before then-if the person is to be detained whilst further investigations take place, the police officer has to make an application to a magistrate for an extension of time, perhaps up to eight hours. We have to give great weight to the fact that this will put a real discipline on the investigating police and provide some reassurance to the suspect that the matter will be reviewed after some four hours.

It is far better if one is trying to ensure the integrity of the criminal justice process that that review takes place on the same day as the questioning rather than perhaps a year or two later at the trial of the accused person where in fact the judge may look back on the events and say, `No, the person was held for what was in excess of what should have been apparent to the police officer was a reasonable time for the line of the investigation and questioning that was being undertaken'. I believe that it is far better for everyone concerned that that matter be determined effectively in a final manner by the magistrate after some four hours.

I believe that the Government legislation does set a balance which should be very acceptable in a democratic society. In this legislation we have overcome a deficiency revealed in the way in which our society can deal with crime. It was a deficiency revealed by the High Court of Australia in the Williams case by empowering investigating police officers to engage in some necessary questioning of a suspect. We have also recognised the very real need to protect those persons who are being subjected to arrest and who are participating in the investigation process by answering a series of questions that have been put to them.

I also emphasise that the Government was happy to make amendments which made absolutely clear that this Bill does not confer any power to arrest. We believe that that was clear in the Bill as it was written. For example, I quote proposed section 23r:
To avoid doubt, it is declared that this Part does not confer any power to arrest a person.

We have doubled up on that provision and made it abundantly clear that nothing in the proposed legislation alters the law so as to give police a power to detain involuntarily. That has been an extension that we have offered to 23r. Quite clearly, as I say, we have affirmed that the Bill does not extend powers of arrest. We have made clear in the earlier sections that we are speaking about lawful arrest-that is, that the power has to be derived from some lawful authority other than by the clauses of this Bill.

The discussion that has taken place in the Committee has been useful. There was an extremely high quality of contribution by all the witnesses to that Committee, who put their cases very forcefully. Those persons who came and gave evidence to the Committee are to be commended for the spirit in which they gave it. Indeed, the Committee is to be commended for the spirit in which it was conducted under the leadership and chairmanship of Senator Cooney-a person of great fame; a Rumpole-type character in the criminal law courts of Victoria-who had a very real passion for getting this legislation right. In chairing this Committee, Senator Cooney has ensured that the Senate has before it a Bill which should receive the support of the whole chamber.

In relation to the Government amendments, I had intended at the commencement of the committee stage to table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the Government amendments to be moved to this Bill. I do so now.

TALK.START.PARA: —According to the proposed schedule, the time has come for us to deal with the Opposition's three amendments that were either accepted during the hearing of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs or, alternatively, were left in a position where there was some support but some further effort in clarification or drafting was desired. It is our view, and certainly the view put by law enforcement authorities, that the court should take into account the number and complexity of the matters being investigated, as one aspect, in order to determine whether the time for the interrogation has been reasonable.

We think another should be added; that is, any reasonable time during which the questioning of the person is suspended or delayed to allow the person to rest or recuperate. TALK.START.PARA: —The Government supports this amendment. So long as the word `reason- able' is given due weight, we think that the person being questioned would not be disadvantaged. SPEECH.PARA: 3. Clause 3, page 5, after proposed paragraph 23C (6) (h), add the following paragraph:
``(j) any reasonable time during which the questioning of the person is suspended or delayed to permit such forensic examinations as are reasonably necessary to the investigation to be conducted.''

The third Opposition amendment also relates to dead time. It is to include another example; that is, reasonable time during which the questioning of the person is suspended or delayed to permit such forensic examinations as are reasonably necessary for the investigation to be conducted. There was considerable evidence put before the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, particularly in relation to drug-type cases, that it is not simply a matter of asking questions but of asking questions in conjunction with forensic evidence, and it takes time for tests to be completed.

The police were concerned that, within these now very strict time limits, if there was not an exclusion for the time taken for this testing it would unreasonably and detrimentally affect their questioning and, therefore, the preparation of their case. We accepted that argument and we put it to the Senate Committee that there should be such an exclusion. Concern was expressed by the Minister and, I think, by Senator Spindler that, as the provision was then drafted, there was no constraint on the time and that this testing might take a considerable period so that the time period as a whole could become unreasonable.

As a result of that, we have inserted at the beginning of this provision, in a similar spirit to the last amendment, that it is only for a reasonable time during which the questioning of the person is suspended to permit those forensic examinations as are reasonably necessary for the investigation to be conducted. We hope that we have now overcome the concerns that were expressed by the Government and by the Australian Democrats. We believe that, if the law enforcement officers need to have additional time to carry out forensic examinations, there is a provision in the Bill for them to ask for an extension for up to eight hours. We believe that to support this amendment, which introduces a high element of uncertainty, would go against the spirit of the Bill as it now stands and would get us back to the arguments that were advanced on the substantive issue between a reasonable time and a certain cap on the hours available for questioning.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have very little to add to the rebuttal offered by Senator Spindler. Although I admit that there has been some modification of the original proposal that was put forward in the Committee on Wednesday morning, nevertheless I believe that the situation would lead to the suspect being uncertain and in no position to ascertain how long the dead time might run. Given the fact that one would be dependent on forces outside the control of the investigating officer and the laboratories that might be undertaking the forensic tests and examinations, I believe that it would be very difficult to ascertain with any definite prediction how long the forensic examination dead time might last. Therefore, I think it has all the difficulties, particularly with the proper addition of the word `reasonable', to open up questions in trials on future occasions which, as Senator Spindler has said, would undo much of the way in which the Bill has now been structured, which has the general concurrence of the Senate. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats have two amendments, both of which were considered during the deliberations of the Committee and both, as it happens, have been somewhat rephrased to meet some concerns that have been expressed. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. Clause 3, page 5, proposed paragraph 23d (2) (b), lines 32 and 33, omit the paragraph, substitute the following paragraphs:
``(b) if it cannot be made at a time when a magistrate is available-a justice of the peace employed in a court of a State or Territory or a bail justice; or

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government accepts this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 2. Clause 3, page 9, proposed subsection 23j (1), line 37, after ``persons'' insert ``(not being constables)''.

This amendment seeks to remove police personnel from the list of interview friends which is made available to people being questioned if they do not have a person whom they could invite to be present as an interview friend. I make it quite clear that we place no bar, and intend to place no bar, against the people being questioned selecting a police officer whom they personally know and trust to become their interview friend in the situation in which they find themselves.

However, it has been put to us by people experienced in the field that when a list of strange names is being provided for a person who is being questioned it is inappropriate to have included on that list police officers who are professional colleagues of the personnel questioning the person arrested. Simply from the point of view of excluding all possibility of placing police personnel in a difficult situation, which could later be challenged, and from the point of view of the person being questioned, we believe that police personnel should be excluded from these lists.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government cannot accept this amendment. I emphasise that we are talking about the drawing up of a list of those persons who might, in a particular region, act as interview friends or interpreters for Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders who are under arrest and investigation for Commonwealth offences. I believe it has to be emphasised that that particular list would be put together, and is required to be put together, in the terms of the Bill. The particular provision states:

SPEECH.PARA: In establishing and maintaining a list in relation to a region, the Minister or his or her delegate must, from time to time, consult with any Aboriginal legal aid organisation providing legal assistance to Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders in that region.

Given that provision, surely no constable would commend himself to the Aboriginal legal aid organisation with which the Minister, or the Minister's delegate, must consult if he was of a disposition which would not be regarded by the Aboriginal suspect as giving grounds for confidence that the interview friend would in fact protect the interests of that person during the interview. I believe that it would be quite unfair and it is-I apologise to Senator Spindler-something of a smear to say that constables cannot be put on the list of those who might act as interview friends and interpreters for Aboriginals or Torres Strait Islanders.

I believe it is important, as the Bill recognises-I do not think it is disputed-that questioning must not take place unless an interview friend is present, or unless the right to have an interview friend has been waived. It seems to me that the compiling of such a list undertaken in that consultative way with an agency-for example, Aboriginal legal aid organisations providing legal assistance-would, after all, lean towards protecting the interests of the suspect. These organisations are obviously very keen to ensure that everybody on the list would be of a type and character that would, as I say, instil confidence in the suspect that his or her rights would be protected during the interview process.
For these reasons, the Government cannot accept that constables should be, as a class-without regard to any qualities whatsoever-excluded from the possibility of being on that list.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In some ways this is a small matter; but it is a difficult matter. On balance, we were of the view in the Committee that the Australian Democrats' amendment should be supported, whilst making it absolutely clear that in doing so there is no intention to smear police officers in any way. Although there is an obligation of consultation, it is the Minister, the Government, that determines the list of persons, interview friends and interpreters that are to help the arrested person in appropriate circumstances. It simply seems to us that it is inappropriate, therefore, to put forward a police officer when another police officer will be conducting the interrogation. I have great respect for police officers and I am sure that those who are put on the list would do their best.

SPEECH.PARA: However, a person attempting to assess the process at a later date would, no doubt, find it somewhat strange and may well be somewhat uncomfortable. Even a court, in looking at it on some future appeal, might well feel somewhat uncomfortable that the aid and support to the interrogated party was another police officer. We do not think it is necessary to get into that difficult area. We cannot imagine any circumstance in which a police officer would be called upon to provide this statutory function. On balance, we support removing any doubt and therefore excluding that particular class of people.

SALES TAX LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 1) 1991

Mr President, this Bill will give effect to the announcement made earlier in the Government's Statement ``Building a Competitive Australia'' of a reduction in the rate of sales tax on `luxury' vehicles to 30%.
The reduced rate of sales tax for `luxury' vehicles will apply to all taxable dealings that occur on or after 13 March 1991.

When the rate of sales tax on `luxury' vehicles was increased by this Government last year, motor vehicles specially fitted out for transporting disabled persons while seated in wheelchairs (which were previously subject to tax at the 30% rate) were excluded from the higher rate of tax and became taxable at the general rate of 20%.
The Bill will ensure that these vehicles remain subject to tax at the lower rate.
The reduction in the rate of sales tax on `luxury' motor vehicles will cost $15 million in 1990-91 and $45 million in 1991-92.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the Senate.
SALES TAX LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1991
Mr President, this Bill will amend the wholesale sales tax law to introduce a system of quarterly payments of sales tax for small business.

As announced by the Treasurer in the 1990-91 Budget, the Bill will amend the sales tax law to give eligible sales taxpayers the option of lodging returns and paying tax on a quarterly rather than a monthly basis.

This measure builds on the Government's previous initiatives to assist small business and it addresses, in part, the recommendations of the Report on Small Business by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology as they relate to the wholesale sales tax system.
Under the current sales tax law, taxpayers who have any taxable dealings in a month are generally required to lodge returns and pay tax within 21 days of the close of that month.
The Bill will allow taxpayers to pay sales tax on a quarterly basis if their annual sales tax liability for the year ended 30 June 1991 was $50,000 or less.

To protect the threshold from erosion by price increases and to ensure that the new system will continue to benefit small taxpayers the threshold will be increased each 1 July in line with movements in the consumer price index.

Eligible taxpayers will have the option of lodging one return for the quarter or a return for each month of the quarter. Such taxpayers may also make payments at any time during the quarter provided that their full sales tax liability for the quarter is paid by the 21st day after the end of the quarter.
Taxpayers will be ineligible to become a quarterly payer if they have not lodged all outstanding returns and paid all outstanding sales tax liabilities.

The new quarterly payments system will apply for taxable dealings that occur on or after 1 August 1991. The first payment of tax under the new system will be due by 21 November 1991 for taxable dealings for the months of August, September and November.

This measure will result in a one-off revenue loss in the 1991-92 financial year by delaying sales tax collections for June of that year and an ongoing interest opportunity cost from delayed collections. The cost will be $49.8m in 1991-92 and $5.9m in 1992-93.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the Senate.
