SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Employment, Education and Training Amendment Bill 1991 was debated in the Senate on 11 and 12 March. On behalf of the Opposition, I moved an amendment which was accepted by the Senate and indeed the debate was completed in my absence. Senator Michael Baume handled this matter for the Opposition in the committee stage and Senator Bell spoke in support. So the Opposition and the Australian Democrats achieved an amendment to this Bill. Yesterday the amended Bill was considered in another place. The House of Representatives disagreed with the amendment. Last night we circulated a message that notes that disagreement and gives two reasons for the disagreement.

SPEECH.PARA: The House of Representatives, in which the Government has a majority, was reluctant to see a reduction in the time that is given for a Minister of the Government to table any report that is received by the Minister-in this case, from the National Board of Employment, Education and Training-and for that report to be published.

The situation up until this time is that the Minister has 15 days to table the report. Our amendment in the Senate was that that time be reduced to five days. Of course, the reasons, in summary, that were given at the time were that we wanted to see a much more speedy receipt by the Parliament and the public of information while it is up to date, and that we did not want to see a government, through its Ministers, being slow in bringing forward information.

Two reasons were given for the House of Representatives disagreeing with this Senate amendment. Of course, the Opposition in the House of Representatives agreed with the amendment. The reasons were: firstly, all other reports of this kind are required to be tabled in 15 days; and, secondly, the longer period, the Government maintains, is required for the reports to be printed.

I can only say that the good objective of our original amendment was to bring to the attention of the Government and the public the widespread discontent with the Government's failure to justify its damaged policies in higher education. We wanted to make sure that this whole Parliament understands that the Government is damaging higher education. Also, the Government ought to make sure that when education advisory bodies bring reports to the Minister, these reports are brought to the Senate while they are fresh because we need to watch what is happening, to receive such advice, and to receive it on time.

The debate now in the two chambers has in fact provided opportunities for our concerns to be made very clear. The Government has been forced to provide detailed justification for the present period of 15 days. I note that the Government, in all this debate, has acknowledged that the actual delay on average over these past two or three years has been 42 calendar days-that is, all reports have on average been tabled in Parliament six weeks after the Minister has received them. I still dispute that 42-day average. I believe that in some instances 8 1/2 to nine calendar weeks have gone by before the Parliament and the public have had access to a report given to the Minister, and yet the Minister does not have to do anything to the report.

All that aside, even considering what the Government has admitted-that is, a delay of 42 days-we have demonstrated that the Government is not meeting its own guidelines. This month the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet (PM and C) has circulated a report entitled Guidelines for the Preparation of Departmental Annual Reports. I know that this refers to departmental annual reports, but there is a reference on page 5 to furnishing and tabling of reports. Paragraph 3.2 states:

Subsection 25 (8) of the Public Service Act requires the Minister to have the report tabled in both Houses of Parliament within 15 sitting days after the day on which the Minister receives the report. The Government has decided that in future the Minister, if 21 calendar days have elapsed, will endeavour to table the annual report within the next three sitting days. Should the statutory 15 sitting day period expire before those three sitting days have elapsed, the Minister would of course be bound to meet the statutory obligation.

Here PM and C defines a higher goal than the statutory requirement. All I can say is that, on the Government's own admission, it is not meeting even the PM and C's guideline on this matter. On page 1716 of the Senate Hansard of 12 March, Senator Michael Baume set out the relevant dates relating to reports over recent years.

Having said all that, I now turn to the speech made by the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) in the House of Representatives yesterday. He referred not only to the two reasons for the House of Representatives message, but made this highly cynical conclusion on page 2168 of Hansard:

It is very likely that the effect of the proposed new clause and amendment would be for the National Board of Employment, Education and Training to delay formal transmission of reports to the Minister in order to allow the necessary time for ministerial approval for printing and tabling.

The Minister threatened that, even if this amendment were to be carried by the Parliament and if there were reduced time for tabling in terms of the statutory requirement, let alone the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet guideline, the Government through its Minister would evade that statutory requirement by ensuring that the report was not received by the Minister until certain administrative matters had been concluded. Then the shorter statutory period could be met, but the whole spirit of what we were after, that is, the speedy publication of information to Parliament and public would be evaded by the Government's cynical administrative procedures.

It is clear from the Minister's speech in Committee in the other place yesterday that the Government has in mind to adopt administrative devices to achieve delays, despite any Opposition amendment and despite guidelines from the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. I hope that the Government will rethink that and will adopt the spirit of our amendment by ensuring that we see a much more speedy publishing of reports in future, especially in the area of higher education. In the circumstances we do not insist on our amendment. It would be pointless to do so because the Government has said that were we to do so it would still evade it. In future some action may be proposed here in the Senate to achieve a more comprehensive solution that will not be able to be eroded by this cynical Government.

I note that one matter that the Senate is to contemplate is that reports of this kind will be tabled in the Senate and House of Representatives before they are printed. I know that there are requirements in our Standing Orders regarding reports once tabled being able to be circulated to all senators, and that would require printing. By an integrated consideration of Standing Orders and our current practice, and with the goal in mind that we have up to date information, we may be able to contemplate and gain unanimous support for such the idea in this Parliament of a Minister tabling almost immediately a report that he receives. If one volume is laid on the table of the Senate and the House of Representatives, as happens when a ministerial statement is circulated prior to its being given under the two-hour rule, arrangements may be made to make duplicated copies available to members until such time as the printed copy is available to everybody.

The advantage of such a procedure, not only in this particular area but more widely and indeed comprehensively, would be that the Parliament would receive reports within a few days of the Minister receiving them rather than 42 days or eight and a half weeks later, without the objections to which Senator Collins and Senator McMullan referred in the Senate debate in March, or indeed those to which the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services referred yesterday. If we were to comprehensively change our procedures in these matters, this would be a test as to whether a government was evading bringing information before the Parliament or whether it was being fair dinkum in reasons such as those we have received from the House of Representatives. I summarise the Opposition's view by saying that, because of the cynical approach by this Government, we will not insist on our amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have very little to add to the description given by Senator Teague as to the reasons for not insisting on this amendment. I think that the matter was well expressed by him. The amendment was not supported originally in a light-hearted manner by the Australian Democrats. The support was given for an amendment that we thought would serve to make a very valuable and important point about the treatment of reports by this Government, and indeed the treatment of reports by Parliament in general.

SPEECH.PARA: That point is also made in the latest issue of the publication Committee Bulletin in the parliamentary committee system. This information is contained in volume 2, No. 2 of February 1991. By coincidence I happened to receive my copy this morning. I was surprised to read on page 4 of that publication the following paragraph:

There are also no hard and fast rules within the bureaucracy as to the timing, form and content of government responses to Parliament reports, which makes the process more unpredictable from the outside. Absence of such guidelines is quite astounding given the importance of the policy issues raised in many reports and given the fact that some inquiries take several years of research and preparation.

I realise that that is not exactly parallel to the concerns that were expressed in this particular piece of legislation but it is relevant and goes alongside the concerns expressed by Senator Teague as to the availability of information to members of Parliament and as to the accuracy and timeliness of such information.

It seems to me to lead to the need to express some sort of caution about allowing these things to get out of hand in terms of the amount of time between reports being delivered to responses being received and reports being tabled. This whole matter needs to be examined. I think that the fact that we have sent the recent amendment to the other place signals a concern. If that has been achieved, then at least I am satisfied with that. We will not continue to make any more fuss about this matter in the hope that the message has been received.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was unfortunate enough to be duty Minister on the last occasion on which this matter came before the Senate. Therefore, I am familiar with this debate. I thank both Senator Teague and Senator Bell for their indications that they will be supporting this motion.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to correct the record. Senator Teague ascribed to the Government a statement which in fact the Government did not make. Indeed, Senator Teague reiterated this matter in his final remarks. He alleged that the Government had said in the House of Representatives that the Government would simply get around these new provisions by some devious means.
When I look at the record, I find that the Government in the House of Representatives said no more than I said in the Senate when this matter was debated, and that was:

It is very likely that the effect of the proposed new clause and amendment would be for the National Board of Employment, Education and Training (NBEET) to delay formal transmission of reports to the Minister in order to allow the necessary time for ministerial approval for printing and tabling.

That does not describe any element of deviousness by the Government. I take that charge seriously: to accuse the Government of trying to deviously outwit a resolution of the Senate requiring the tabling of a report is a serious charge to make, and it is refuted.

We were simply stating the fact that the new proposed reporting timetable would have been so onerous and so difficult to meet that, in order not to breach the new rules, the organisation itself may well have been forced into delaying the actual transmission of the document until it had had time for approval, printing and tabling so it would not be in breach of the new arrangements. PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 13 March, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Amendment Bill 1991, which deals, as one might gather from its title, with the ongoing saga of the electoral system in the Australian Capital Territory. The Australian Capital Territory achieved self-government with the passage of the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Act 1988, and the electoral system for the Territory was specified in the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Act 1988. This system-termed `modified d'Hondt'-was adopted as a compromise following a drawn out and lengthy debate, and provided for a form of proportional representation not previously used in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The first elections for the ACT Legislative Assembly were held on 4 March 1989; and, as everyone in this place knows, the exercise was perceived to have left a lot to be desired. It is fair to say, however, that virtually any electoral system adopted would have had difficulty in coping with the peculiar circumstances of that election.

Most people would agree that there is no doubt that many of the problems revolved around entrenched opposition to self-government. I remind the Senate that there were 117 candidates for 17 positions and that the ballot paper was a metre wide, with 139 boxes. The two major parties attracted less than 40 per cent of first preference votes with 60 per cent of preferences following no consistent pattern. In the event, groups such as the Sun-Ripened Warm Tomato Party, the Surprise Party, the Party! Party! Party! Party and so on did not win a seat, but as a result of their mischief-and I think that is the best way to describe it-it took some nine weeks for the results of the election to become clear.

Subsequently, a subcommittee of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters-ably chaired by my colleague, the honourable member for Chisholm, Dr Michael Wooldridge-inquired into the election. That Committee canvassed exhaustively the history of the ACT electoral system and the experiences gained at the first election. It described the tortuous nature of the negotiations that led to the final outcome. Given the way that the modified d'Hondt system was adopted, it is not surprising that the Committee's report was illustrated with a camel-highlighting the well known maxim that a camel is a horse designed by a committee.

As a threshold question, and in retrospect, we could well ask why this Parliament retained control over the electoral laws of the ACT and did not give them that power in the first place. After all, I understand that when the Northern Territory achieved self-government electoral laws were included in the powers given to the elected assembly, as is only logical. By now, however, residents of the national capital have had self-government for nearly three years. Surely, it is appropriate for them to decide the alternative they prefer. It is my understanding that the Government intends to give them that.

I am pleased that the Government has committed itself to holding a referendum to allow the residents of the ACT to choose the system that will be used. The choice being offered will be either the Hare-Clark proportional representation system or single member electorates. Further, the Opposition supports the repatriation of electoral laws to the ACT so that in future this Parliament will not have to concern itself with the minutiae of ACT electoral matters.

Because of the Government's commitment both to hold a referendum and to repatriate the electoral legislation after the 1992 elections, we are able to take a different attitude to the Bill now before the Senate. The Opposition voted against this Bill in the lower House because, although we supported many of its provisions-and provisions recommended by the Standing Committee-we could not support the basic thrust of changes to the method of voting.

What the Government had proposed was to prevent voters from distributing preferences across party lines; in other words, they were to be locked into a party list. We accept that this procedure would have shortened the time needed to obtain a result but believe that denying freedom of choice was too high a price to pay for this time saving.

Following our opposition to the Bill in the House of Representatives and expressions over here that we could not support the Bill with the preferences limited to party lists, at the request of the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories (Mr Simmons) I had discussions with him, following which he wrote me a letter in which he incorporated his proposal to address the concerns that we had expressed, pointing out the proposal for a referendum and for transferring the power to control the electoral system over to the Assembly. That letter to me was dated 14 March.

On behalf of the Liberal and National parties, I subsequently responded on 4 April and indicated to him that we agreed in principle with the proposal he had made in his previous letter, with one or two small reservations. One reservation was that we wished to be assured that the questions asked in the referendum and explanatory information provided with those questions would be framed in such a way as to be equitable to both options. The other reservation was-and this indicated no doubt on the intent of the Minister but was simply a matter of prudence-that we would need to see the proposed amendments to ensure there were no unintended consequences.

We maintain our position on this issue of preferences and look forward to the Government moving amendments to abandon this proposal. Further, we also objected to the proposal to limit the deadline for the receipt of postal votes, thus requiring votes to be received by the close of polling on election day. The present time allowance of two weeks after polling day is designed to ensure that no voters are disenfranchised, and this is consistent with the practice in Federal elections.

In the other place the Minister noted that the Government was relaxed about this issue, and I trust that this amendment will return to the current time-frame. While it is appreciated that with the ACT the election date is known, it seemed to us that restricting the postal votes to the election date would not save any time simply because, as is the case now, the preferences could be distributed across the voting paper. We were also somewhat concerned that some enthusiastic person might decide to use it as a precedent in other elections, which we believe would be very much a backward step.

There are a number of reforms recommended by the Joint Standing Committee which the Opposition has always supported. We understand that the Government's amendments will preserve those sensible changes. Many of them could be described as merely housekeeping and would overcome some of the worst features of the previous system. In brief they will provide, firstly, that political parties must have existing parliamentary representation, or at least 100 members, to be eligible to maintain registered status; and, secondly, that no individual may register or be the registered officer for more than one political party-and there are good reasons for supporting that. It stops one individual registering some 40 or 50 parties and acting as their registered officer simply to distort the electoral system. As I mentioned earlier, very few electoral systems could have withstood the pressure that occurred at the first election. The third point is that the deposit required from candidates nominating for election be raised to $250, which brings it into line with the House of Representatives and, I understand, most States. Fourthly, the amendments will provide for clearer, more logical rules about formality, and, fifthly, they will provide for the Electoral Commission to conduct a two-stage count allowing an indication of election outcomes to be obtained on the night of the election. I think that is important.

I note that the debate on this Bill in the lower House canvassed a number of other matters. For example, I read with interest the contribution of the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Mack), who floated the suggestion that the ACT should be `disappeared'-to use his words-as a separate entity and included in New South Wales. I am not sure how the Government and the people of New South Wales, or the people of the ACT, would respond to this proposal, but I would point out that there would be major difficulties in achieving it, which obviously the honourable member for North Sydney did not contemplate, because of the necessity to change the Constitution.

Some speakers in the other place rather mischievously, I thought, tried to turn the debate into a consideration of the merits of voluntary voting, and I note the comments of the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths). I would be happy at any time to have a full-scale debate on that subject and note that this very fundamental change to our electoral system was enacted in 1924 in less than 2 1/2 hours, without a division in either House.

One of the difficulties of the legislation-and this was commented on by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee-is that the legislation that covers the ACT electoral system is not limited to one Act of Parliament but to a number of Acts. It is worth quoting what the Committee said:

The Committee is of the view that this situation presents a person who wishes to look up the electoral law that applies to the ACT with a very confusing task. A person would have to refer to three separate pieces of legislation, including cross-referencing four different Schedules, in order to establish what the electoral law is.

This was highlighted by the fact that when the Bill was passed in the House of Representatives the Opposition took a view that, while it could support most of the Government amendments as recommended by the Standing Committee, it could not support the proposal which limited the preference to party lists. It was interesting that counsel engaged by the clerks to provide proposed amendments which would satisfy our requirements found it to be a daunting task. If those experts had a daunting task, what hope is there for ordinary senators to be able to contemplate an issue such as this? I understand that it is the intent of the Government to refer this Bill to a committee to review the proposed committee stage amendments, and that those amendments will embody the changes outlined to me by the Minister in his letter of 14 March.

In conclusion, the situation as it now stands is that, as I understand it, the people of the ACT will go to the next election under a system which has improvements based on the recommendations of the Standing Committee but which preserves the right of voters to place their preferences where they wish. At the same time, they will vote in a referendum to determine the type of electoral system they want and, based on the outcome of that referendum, future determinations of the electoral system in the ACT will be determined by the ACT Assembly itself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is somewhat unusual for me to be speaking at this stage in the debate, but I thought it appropriate that someone on behalf of the Government should put formally in the debate the changes to the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Amendment Bill which will be proposed subsequently and which Senator Parer has referred to. I realise that Senators Reid and Bell would not be handicapped in participating if I did not because they know broadly, as I do, what is involved in those matters, but it just seemed appropriate, in terms of properly conducting the debate, if, rather than speak later, I did it early just for the sake of the record showing that the changes were outlined in broad intent and that people were able then to speak about them.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no real secret about what we are now proposing to do, and that has been accurately reflected by Senator Parer's comments. Firstly, this Bill will be substantially amended to restrict it to those provisions retaining bipartisan support, and those matters were outlined by Senator Parer accurately in the second reading debate. The Bill will also be amended to provide for a referendum to determine the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) electorates preferred electoral system. It is a fairly substantial task of drafting to have those amendments done but we are now engaged in a process which will enable us at the end of the second reading debate to refer it to the appropriate committee. In the course of this session we hope to have the legislation concluded so that the people in the ACT know what that electoral system is-although effectively they do now-and know the manner in which the referendum will be conducted. The contest for the election and the debate around the referendum can then proceed in a proper and informed manner for the remaining period.

Perhaps to the relief of the people of the ACT-perhaps not-the next election is approaching remarkably rapidly. The election will be held early in February, which is some 10 months away. But the real significance of it is that most of the effective campaign, particularly on the more esoteric matters such as the electoral system, will need be concluded by Christmas so that people can concentrate on the issues dealing with formation of Government itself.

So the period from when we get this Bill passed, say some time in May, is not a long one for what is a fairly important debate, even if it is easier to conduct in a smaller and more compact community such as the ACT. I will not reiterate, as I was otherwise going to, the matters of agreement because Senator Parer has done that adequately. As I have said, the Government's timetable with regard to those changes is broadly that we will be seeking to have the committee report back in May and we will be trying to conclude the legislation in the course of this session.

I welcome the changes that have been agreed upon. Notwithstanding that clearly the Government would have preferred more substantial changes, they will be improvements which will be welcomed. The capacity effectively to be confident of the election outcome on the night, even if it is not finalised, will substantially enhance the reputation of both the system and self-government itself. There is no doubt that the counting process and the delayed outcome last time were substantial debilitating factors, as were the proliferation of parties and the deliberate attempts to make the transfer of responsibility to the ACT into a farce. I suppose one can say that that was successful.

I suppose one should say, to be fair to the d'Hondt electoral system, that it is actually not a bad electoral system. As Senator Parer said, it was put under extraordinary strain by the arrangements that individuals made in the manner in which they sought to contest the last election. It is not, of itself, a bad system although by the time the Senate had finished amending it, the one that we gave the ACT as a so-called modified d'Hondt had its shortcomings. The basic d'Hondt system is not a bad system but it is totally discredited in the ACT.

It is impossible, beyond this next election, to proceed with further elections under it. That is not because the result will be so unfair or so unreasonable-I do not believe that the last election result was unfair-the problem with it is that it reflected accurately the votes of the electors. They turned out and voted for the people who got elected. It is very hard to find in the streets of Canberra the people who voted for Craig Duby. By normal laws of arithmetic about 14 per cent of the people out there should have voted for him, but of every 100 people I meet I do not find one who admits to it, except Craig. I have found nobody else-and sometimes he is not sure.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should not reflect badly on members of other parliaments.

—It may have been a compliment. The people of the ACT are expressing grave reservations about the outcome of that election. People tend to blame the electoral system for the outcome, but that is not reasonable. The d'Hondt system did that which it purports to do well-it delivered a result that essentially reflected the intentions of the voters when they went to the ballot box.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us come back to some sort of history of how we got to that d'Hondt system as a bit of background to properly assessing where we should proceed from here. I do not want to do that at great length but I think it is important, for a complete picture, that we give some indication of how it is that we got to this stage.

Of course, there had been a lot of discussion about electoral systems for the ACT in the various discussions about self-government. Various forms of proportional representation had been contemplated at different times-different numbers of electorates and different types of electoral systems-but this Government, from the time it took office and expressed a desire for and commitment to achieve self-government, always indicated as its preferred option a single member electorate system. I am not saying that that was the only proposal we ever put forward, because we were aware that there was never a majority in the Senate for that proposal, but it was and remains the Government's preferred option. I will come back to my case for that subsequently. I am simply now making the historical point that that is where we started.

We were forced to seek a proposal that could win majority support in the Senate. We did not want another so-called butcher of self-government incident. I believe that it was correct that we entered into that process of negotiation, notwithstanding its frustrations and notwithstanding, to some extent, the inadequacy of the outcome. The greater objective of transferring responsibility for their own affairs to the people of the ACT-the greater objective of self-government-needed to be achieved and was more important than the short term detail of the electoral system.

I share with Senator Parer the view which I expressed in my party room then, and I am now happy that it has been achieved, that the electoral system should have been handed over then, but there was not the confidence of people in this Parliament-I think on all sides of the Parliament-that the Assembly would be a body to which people were happy to hand over the electoral system. It may be that the result of the first election justifies the caution of people on both sides of the chamber. That is a matter for debate. I am not sure that that is correct, but I can see that people would perhaps feel justified. Nevertheless, it is appropriate that we should now be proceeding to hand over. It was more important that the major issue of self-government was achieved than that the minor issue of under which electoral system it should operate and that should not be allowed to continue to obstruct the achievement of that objective.

There was a lengthy and frustrating negotiating process in which I was involved. One of the most frustrating features about the continuing discussion about ACT electoral systems has been that some people-not senators present, but the Australian Democrats' representatives at that time-did not seem to understand what negotiation meant. They put forward their proposal and everybody else put forward theirs. We would then enter into a long series of discussions about possible variations and they would nod and say, `That is interesting', and come back the next day and say, `Thank you very much, but our view is exactly what it was yesterday'. They would seek compromises from everybody else but in the end it was impossible to come to any agreement with the Democrats because they could not see the wood for the trees. There had to be some other form of agreement which was eventually arrived at, and an electoral system was agreed which led to that last election.

As I have said before, whatever the lack of legitimacy of d'Hondt in the eyes of the ACT people-and there is no doubt that that is there and that it is necessary to come up with a mechanism for replacing it, and the referendum is the appropriate mechanism at this time-the election result last year reflected the wishes of the voters.

I turn to consider this Bill before us now-and I will not dwell on what it might have been-as I have outlined it, with the changes which the Government intends to pursue in the committee stage. The Bill, as originally introduced by the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray), was not that which I would have preferred. I have publicly and privately supported a referendum for some time. I welcome the fact that the Bill is now going to reflect that objective. Even before that objective was achieved, I welcomed the commitment by the Minister in the second reading speech to transfer responsibility to the ACT to determine the electoral system. In the Westminster system of government, under which we operate, that is the alternative mechanism and the normal, standard and appropriate mechanism for determining the preferences of electors on major issues.

We do not have referendums on major issues-they are not appropriate for resolution in that manner. I think electoral systems are somewhat different. In the normal course of events what happens, and what will happen with regard to all of the other issues in the ACT-what people want to do about the hospital system or the school system-is that people put forward alternative packages of policies to the electorate, and the electorate chooses through the ballot box and elects the government on the basis of its judgment about the balance of policies which those people put forward. That is how the Westminster system allows those decisions to be made. It is how governments are formed and how the policy process has proceeded traditionally. I thought that was, of itself, an appropriate mechanism-and it would have been-but I prefer the referendum model and I am pleased that we are going in that direction.

The ACT people will get a new electoral system and the opportunity to indicate what electoral system it is that they would prefer. It will be a very brave ACT government which does not act in accordance with that. There is no doubt that everybody campaigning at the next election here will have to commit themselves to accepting the outcome of the referendum. It is inconceivable that anybody would contemplate not doing it as a matter of democratic process, but as a matter of electoral reality no-one would be able to withstand the pressure of saying, `We would not accept the outcome of the referendum'. Although the legislation will not make the referendum outcome binding, it will be binding-it will bind people effectively politically, and it should.

To achieve that, as I have said, we have a fairly strict timetable, because we do need to be able to get the legislation passed in sufficient time for people to know what they are campaigning about for an extended period and so that the education process, the communications process and the process of democratic consideration can proceed. We have encountered some stumbling blocks before getting to the point of holding a referendum; one of which I think was perfectly legitimate. The question of cost is not one that can be brushed aside. It is all very well for people to say-not many people are still saying it-that the referendum should have been conducted earlier because it would not cost much money. The first point I make is that it is other people's money; it is the taxpayers' money and if we can do something for no cost or, alternatively, we can spend several hundred thousand dollars doing it, we would be absolutely irresponsible to choose the expensive option instead of the more cost efficient one.

I think the current proposal to hold a referendum is an excellent outcome. It significantly reduces the cost to virtually nothing and it also avoids the inconvenience of conducting a separate referendum. It does mean that we will have to conduct the next election under d'Hondt, only slightly improved. I would have thought that, with a bit more cooperation-I am not being critical of anyone here, I think all of us probably fell a bit short-we could have found a compromise electoral system once we had decided that we were going to have a referendum. But no parties-including my own-have chosen to pursue that route. I am, therefore, happy that we are proceeding to the referendum. That is the most important thing and it will resolve the question.

I will be supporting the single member constituencies option in that referendum. That will be a surprise to no one; I have said it on very many occasions. I said it in about the first speech I made as an elected representative of the ACT in 1988. It is very easy for people to be cynical and say that the Labor Party in the ACT or I support single member constituencies only because we think we will win under that system. I have supported single member constituencies as the appropriate electoral system for the Northern Territory for 20 years and my Party has never won there. We did not win any seats in the first election which was held in the Northern Territory, but that did not lead me to say, `Let's find a new electoral system under which we can do a bit better'. I supported the continuation of single member constituencies. There are other States in which the Labor Party has had notorious lack of success-fortunately in some cases this has been redressed recently-but there was never a suggestion in any of those mainland States that there should be a change of the electoral system in favour of adopting the proportional representation system.

What I find somewhat more surprising is those parties whose policy changes from State to State, depending upon whether they think they can win under one particular system or another. At least the Democrats are consistent; they always support the only system under which they could get elected, and then accuse everybody else of self-interest. We have a situation where, in my view--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.
—It is absolutely accurate, and the honourable senator knows that it is. History proves it to be correct.
—We are just a proportion.

—Under proportional representation in the ACT the Democrats could not even win here last time, but I assume that they will not have quite the same self-destructive streak next time. We will see what the electors decide.
—Put up Norm Sanders.

—If they did that I suspect they would do better than they did last time. I want to outline, very briefly-because there will be plenty more opportunities to do it, and I will take them; and because I think that it is important and, in a sense, it is the first time we have discussed the electoral system which will result from the referendum-the fundamental reasons why I will support that system. First and foremost, it is a system that the people of the ACT understand and are comfortable with. It does have that degree of democratic legitimacy which d'Hondt lacks. That factor should not be underestimated. It is very important that we say to the people of the ACT that the system of democracy which exists now-the democratic process of determining priorities between people in the ACT as they proceed to resolve issues in conflict-needs to have that degree of legitimacy which democratic government requires. Therefore, I think it needs the electoral system that most people in mainland Australia regard as being the way in which people choose governments.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a large number of other factors concerning the importance of a local member-based system, for government and for the people. It both assists individuals and, in my view, makes for better government. It also means that voters can choose the person that they wish to represent them in their local area and they can exercise a clear choice between identifiable individuals whom they can scrutinise. That is particularly appropriate in a Territory such as this.

The most important reason why I have always supported the single member constituency option is that it means that candidates have to be able to command majority support in at least one area of the electorate. In effect, that means that, over the ACT as a whole, parties aspiring to form government have to put forward a comprehensive package of policies across a range of issues. They have to say, `If we are the Government this is how we will address education; this is how we will address health'. People cannot then get elected by ignoring 19 of the 20 key issues and concentrating on only one because they know that maybe 5 per cent of the electorate is concerned about it. I do not care whether the 5 per cent are people who have views with which I agree or disagree; I do not believe the appropriate mechanism for choosing a government is the fortunate coincidence of cobbling together a number of individuals and groups who have put together sectional interest-appealing policies. I will be mounting that argument on a more comprehensive basis over the weeks and months to come. Obviously, like everybody else in Canberra, I will accept the outcome of the referendum, whichever way it goes. It will not change my preference for what I think the better system is, but I will certainly accept the wish of the people as expressed.

The next task we have-it is not an easy one-is to formulate the questions that need to be put in the referendum. In one sense it is terribly easy. We will say that one will be, effectively, the House of Representatives system and one will be Hare Clark. But what sort of Hare Clark will we have? My personal view is that the Government should not try to choose that. The people who advocate it should, in some way, choose what sort of Hare Clark system we will be putting forward to the people.

The main problem I have found is identifying what Hare Clark means to the people who advocate it. It has many advocates, but they all think it means something slightly different. Malcolm Mackerras started off from a position of support for three electorates of seven members. He stated that that was the only way that we would have real Hare Clark because we had to have even numbers in the electorates. He has now changed his view and favours two electorates of five members, and one of seven members. The view he put to the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters was slanted in that direction.

The Proportional Representation Society of Australia originally favoured Hare Clark with some minor technical modifications taken from the Tasmanian model. It was not sure, at that stage, how many electorates it wanted-probably two. However, it was definitely opposed to electorates with only five members. That is leading to a situation whereby if there are 17 members there would have to be two constituencies-there is no other way that 17 people could be elected without at least one of the electorates having five people in it. That was the Society's option then. I am advised, upon reading the Canberra Times of 23 March, that it now favours the so-called Buchanan model, which I will talk about later. I must admit that the Buchanan model reminds me somewhat of an Edsel.

The Australian Democrats originally proposed what they called the discrete community system, in which the ACT would be broken up into four defined areas with members allocated to each area on the basis of enrolment. They said that the four defined areas would be Belconnen, central Canberra, Woden-Weston Creek and Tuggeranong. Conveniently, they would come up with four or five members for each of those and, conveniently, each electorate would be just of the size--

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to speak briefly on the impact of the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade tabled last year on Australia-India relations. This report shows what can be achieved by a parliamentary committee in this place. Committees can advise, inform, educate and influence policy. I would like to congratulate my colleagues on the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade for their work on that inquiry and for their work in the preparation of the report. As is the case with all standing committees, there were eight members on this Committee. Over the course of two parliaments, there have been more than eight senators involved in the preparation of this particular report, which was tabled here in August last year.

SPEECH.PARA: There were two principal recommendations: firstly, for the establishment of an Australia-India council, an advisory body to develop the relationship in the broad between the two countries and, secondly, for an Indian studies centre, which was to be a centre of excellence in a major Australian university. It was to be a repository of expertise on India in this country. The objective was to seek private sector funding for it. The Committee in its deliberations discovered that many of the Australian experts on India in our universities were about to retire and this was one of the reasons for the recommendations.

In December, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans, responded to the report, as was required, and he endorsed the Australia-India council. He indicated that he would seek funds in the next Budget in August for that council. I think it is fair to say that in respect of the Indian studies centre, the Minister endorsed the idea in principle, but he came back to the Committee and suggested to us that we come up with further details and further proposals to refine that particular recommendation.

During the Easter recess of the past three weeks, I took the opportunity to travel to India. I went there to publicise the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. While there, I had meetings in Bombay and New Delhi. In Bombay, I met with leading figures in the commerce, trade and financial sectors. In New Delhi, I discussed the report with political leaders, diplomats and government leaders.

There was great interest in the report in New Delhi. In fact, I did not have to publicise it in the business and government circles because people were very well informed on the report and had read it. Many people made very positive comments on the report and there was also very positive comment on Minister Evans's response to the Committee recommendations last December. In fact, one leading industrialist in Bombay even provided me with a written critique of the report. It was a very positive critique which showed that people in the top positions were taking the time to read the report of the Senate Committee.

I have no doubt that the report has had a modest positive impact on Australian-Indian relations. I would not want to overstate it but, certainly in business and political circles, it was regarded very favourably. On leaving New Delhi last Thursday, I was told that the report is now being sold to other embassies in that capital city as it is regarded as being the most concise contemporary document on India and on one country's relationship with India.

In official and business circles, the response to the report has been overwhelmingly positive. It is certainly a major talking point with the political and business elites in the country and, in a very modest way, it has helped to add to Australia's credibility in India. The report is now in its third or fourth print run and I understand that yet another large order was submitted for the report last week.

As chairman of the Committee, in India I had the privilege of meeting with Mr Rajiv Gandhi last Thursday. I spent considerable time with him at his campaign headquarters discussing a range of issues relating to Australia. The focus was on economic issues and the talks were very productive. I also had the opportunity to speak with three Ministers in the present Indian Government, including Mr A K Sen who, as the Minister of steel and mines, takes a great interest in the importation of Australian coal, which is our major export to that country.

I also had the opportunity to meet with the governor of the Reserve Bank, Mr Venkitamanan. I was able to do that despite the very severe economic problems that India was having at the time. I was most impressed that he was able to see me, given that he had the International Monetary Fund knocking on the door to talk about India's foreign exchange problems. In addition to the many business leaders I met, I also had a round table discussion on the report with representatives of various think-tanks and universities in New Delhi.

I believe that Australian business should look now at investing in India. While there are foreign exchange programs at the moment, there could well be relaxation of economic controls after the elections next month, and I believe that the complex Indian system of licensing, of tariffs and of foreign exchange controls will be under the microscope in the aftermath of the Indian general elections. I believe that Australian business should get in now. Certainly, in the past, India has not attracted a great deal of foreign investment, but that situation could well change.

I believe that there is more scope for cooperation between the two countries and certainly more scope for stronger political and business links. No doubt members of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade will be looking at the May election results with great interest and they will be looking for any consequent changes in policy stemming from those elections.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my first speech in this place in September of last year, one of the issues on which I commented was the subject of the lack of accreditation in this country of private training providers. I illustrated, by way of example, some difficulties that were occurring with two private training providers in the hospitality industry in my home State of Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: Regrettably in this country there is no formal registration of private training providers. With the explosion of private training in this country, a number of instances of malpractice have emerged. On the first occasion that I spoke on this matter, I drew to the attention of the Senate claims in brochures that the courses that were being offered had some form of accreditation. That was incorrect. The place at which the training was taking place, in this case Wrest Point, gave the impression that that workplace itself, which has a high reputation in the hospitality industry, was carrying out the training, when in fact it was not. There was a range of other problems, some particularly serious, which I will comment on at another time, which verge on criminal practice.

In the case of one of the two training operators, I am pleased to say that, following my speech to this place, I received some contact from that organisation known as the Hospitality Training Group. The managing director of that organisation is Ms Natasha Lakajev. She contacted me following my speech. I did in fact write to her expressing my concerns about a number of that company's practices. I have to emphasise that problems that I believe occurred in this training program are minor compared to problems in the other training program which, as I said, I will be referring to at a later time.

I pointed out to the Hospitality Training Group that I believed that its pamphlet was misleading. Having talked to Ms Lakajev, I do not believe that that was intentional, but the pamphlet was misleading. It referred to accreditation when in fact it had not received accreditation at that point in time. There is an organisation in the hospitality industry known as Tourism Training Australia, which is recognised by all the various parties within the industry as the appropriate body to provide accreditation through a subcommittee known as the Australian hospitality review panel.

Following my conversations with the managing director of the Hospitality Training Group, members of the group have received accreditation in a number of the training modules that they offer to the public. Those training modules are introductory food and beverage, customer relations and interpersonal skills. The group was granted accreditation provided that greater emphasis was placed on team- work in the teaching of the interpersonal skill module and, when advertising, that reference to work experience is omitted as it is neither guaranteed nor supervised.

Further to that, on the written material that the members of the particular training group publish and on their registration forms, they must state which modules they have accreditation for so that students are made aware of the level and extent of accreditation. These matters, whilst important, are relatively minor compared with the malpractices that go on in the private training area in other areas. Following Miss Natasha Lakajev's communication with me, I assured her that I would bring to the attention of the Senate the fact that her training scheme is operating under the auspices of, and with the full accreditation of, Tourism Training Australia and that I would not hesitate to recommend her course in terms of its accreditation, fitness and proper course content to persons who wish to undertake training in the hospitality industry.

As I mentioned earlier, there is one other particular scheme-there may be others-I have been made aware of which, I understand, given what has been presented to me in the last six months, is carried out in a criminal manner. I have initiated particular actions in regard to that scheme and will be reporting on that at another time.

I conclude my remarks by saying that, regrettably, these incidents, and others which I am aware of in other industries, illustrate the need for some form of formal accreditation. If the burgeoning and rapidly expanding private training sector-about whose existence I do not have any complaint-continues to expand, it should offer training in a proper and accredited form in order that persons who undertake private training are well aware of what they are being trained for and that they are receiving value for money.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

ANSWER.PARA: (2) $71,026 (on facilities, i.e. on building modifications and fittings).

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The rules that apply to the commencement of sole parent's pension are the same as those that apply to all other types of pensions. Payment generally commences from the first available payday following the date on which the claim was lodged (between 1 and 13 days after lodgement). There is no waiting period of the sort that applies in respect of unemployment benefit.

Sole parent's pension is not a payment made only for the reason that a woman gives birth. Sole parent's pension is payable to parents, either male or female, or to the long-term custodians of children on the basis of the parental responsibilities involved.

In the majority of instances the events which may cause a person to apply for sole parent's pension are recent birth of a child, separation from a spouse, death of a spouse or imprisonment of a spouse.

New applicants for sole parent's pension are required to provide details of any recent employment history in order to verify that earnings have ceased, or to establish what rate of earnings will continue. These details are relevant to applying the income test and determining the appropriate rate of pension.

Specific information on the reason for leaving employment, where this is applicable, is not available. This is not necessary to the determination of entitlement and, in accordance with privacy principles, is not collected.
(2) No, although details, including information about the former employment, are obtained.
(3) Yes. The precise detailed information sought is not available.
Data indicate that over 80% of JET clients overall have been on pension for 12 months or more.

The Interim Evaluation Report on JET also indicates that a recent work history is very relevant to obtaining further employment outcomes. In those instances where a sole parent pensioner has recently left the workforce early JET intervention is usually very cost effective.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 5 March 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware of the devastation the people of Eugowra, NSW, have experienced because of the Mandagery Creek flood which inundated the township and surrounding land on 2 September 1990, which was the worst flood experienced by the town in 100 years.

(2) Given that a means test, which is almost below the poverty line, prevented most families from obtaining assistance for the loss of wages and personal belongings, and given that the people of Nyngan were given assistance at the time of the flood in 1990, is the Government prepared to offer similar assistance to the people of Eugowra.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) Emergency relief and financial assistance for the loss of personal belongings in a disaster are State responsibilities. In New South Wales they are dealt with by the Department of Family and Community Services. The Commonwealth contributes disaster relief under the Natural Disaster Relief Arrangements and through the Social Security system.

Department of Social Security (DSS) staff visited the area and made income support payments available to disaster victims in accordance with the Social Security Act. In most cases this was payment of special benefit. Of 30 claims received, 28 were approved.
Special benefit payments replace loss of wages in the short-term until a return to work is possible, or until those affected are able to qualify for unemployment benefit.

The people of Eugowra received DSS assistance similar to that provided in Nyngan. The situation was kept under close observation, with follow up visits by senior staff to ensure that all those entitled to assistance from the Department had the opportunity to receive it.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Committees on World Heritage Listed Wet Tropics

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 13 March 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) (a) By which process were members of the Community Consultative Committee and Scientific Advisory Committee on World Heritage Listed Wet Tropics chosen;
(b) what were the dates of appointment;
(c) who chose the committee members; and
(d) on what criteria were selection for appointment to the committees based?

(2) Will members of the Community Consultative Committee and the Scientific Advisory Committee on World Heritage Listed Wet Tropics receive any payments from the Federal or Queensland Government in return for their participation on the committees; if so, how much money will be paid to each member of both the Community Consultative Committee and the Scientific Advisory Committee?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) For the selection of members to the Community Consultative Committee, nominations were sought from the public through advertisements in North Queensland newspapers and directly from interest groups. A joint Ministerial press statement was also issued inviting members of the public to nominate for the Community Consultative Committee. Nominations for the Scientific Advisory Committee were sought from Commonwealth and Queensland Government sources.

(b) The Chairman and members of the Community Consultative Committee were appointed for a period of 3 years from 1 March 1991. The Chairman of the Scientific Advisory Committee was appointed for a term of 3 years from 10 August 1990 and members for 3 years from 1 March 1991.

(c) The committee members were chosen by the Wet Tropics Ministerial Council, comprising the Queensland Environment and Heritage Minister, Mr Pat Comben (Chairman), Queensland Primary Industries Minister, Mr Ed Casey, Commonwealth Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Mrs Ros Kelly, and the Commonwealth Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Northern Australia, Senator Bob Collins.
(d) The following criteria were used in the selection of the members of the Community Consultative Committee:
- Desirable that nominees be members of the north Queensland community.
- Desirable that nominees be representative of the north Queensland community in the interest area for which they were nominated.
In this regard, the following interest areas are specified in the Wet Tropics World Heritage Area Management Scheme:
- Local government
- scientific community
- conservation
- industrial unions
- education
- recreation
- Aboriginal community
- tourism
- mining
- commerce
- primary production
- individual with outstanding knowledge of the Area.
The following criteria were used for the selection of the members of the Scientific Advisory Committee:
- Eminence in a scientific field directly relevant to the science of management of the Wet Tropics including botany, zoology, ecology, biogeography, hydrology and conservation land management.
- An outstanding record of research in an area directly relevant to management of the Wet Tropics.
- Research expertise in the Wet Tropics.
- Knowledge of the requirements for development and/or implementation of management plans for natural areas.
- A demonstrated interest in nature conservation.
- Ability to apply their scientific expertise to conservation of a World Heritage Area.
(2) Membership to the committees is honorary; however, travel and other costs are paid at the rates set by the Remuneration Tribunal for part-time holders of public office.
